CHAPTER 101
Codified Ordinances
101.01   Designation; citation; headings.
101.02   General definitions.
101.03   Rules of construction.
101.04   Revivor; effect of amendment or repeal.
101.05   Construction of section references.
101.06   Conflicting provisions.
101.07   Determination of legislative intent.
101.08   Severability.
101.99   General penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   See sectional histories for similar State law
   Statute of limitations on prosecutions - see Ohio R.C. 718.06; GEN. OFF.
501.06
   Codification in book form - see Ohio R.C. 731.23
   Imprisonment until fine and costs are paid - see Ohio R.C. 1905.30, 2947.14
   Citation issuance for minor misdemeanors - see Ohio R.C. 2935.26 et seq.
   Rules of construction for offenses and penalties - see GEN. OFF.
501.04
   101.01 DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS.
   (a)   All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the Municipality
as revised, codified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component
codes, titles, chapters and sections shall be known and designated as the
Codified Ordinances of Sandusky, Ohio, 1997 for which designation "Codified
Ordinances" may be substituted. Code, title, chapter and section headings do
not constitute any part of the law as contained in the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.01)
   (b)   All references to codes, titles, chapters and sections are to such
components of the Codified Ordinances unless otherwise specified. Any component
code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the "Traffic Code".
Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation "Section" followed by
the number, such as "Section
101.01".
   101.02  GENERAL DEFINITIONS.
   As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless another definition is provided or
the context otherwise requires:
(a)   "And" may be read "or", and "or" may be read "and", if the sense requires
it.
      (ORC 1.02(F))
(b)   "Another" when used to designate the owner of property which is the
subject of an offense, includes not only natural persons but also every other
owner of property.
      (ORC 1.02(B))
(c)   "Bond" includes an undertaking and "undertaking" includes a bond.
   (ORC 1.02(D), (E))
(d)   "Council" means the legislative authority of the Municipality.
(e)   "County" means Erie County, Ohio
(f)   "Keeper" or "proprietor" includes all persons, whether acting by
themselves or as a servant, agent or employee.
(g)   "Land" or "real estate" includes rights and easements of an incorporeal
nature.
   (ORC 701.01(F))
(h)   "Municipality" or "City" means the City of Sandusky, Ohio.
(i)   "Oath" includes affirmation and "swear" includes affirm.
   (ORC 1.59(B))
(j)   "Owner", when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint owner
or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
(k)   "Person" includes an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership and association.
      (ORC 1.59(C))
(l)   "Premises", as applied to property, includes land and buildings.
(m)   "Property" means real and personal property.
   (ORC 1.59(E))
   "Personal property" includes all property except real.
   "Real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
(n)   "Public authority" includes boards of education; the Municipal, County,
State or Federal government, its officers or an agency thereof; or any duly
authorized public official.
(o)   "Public place" includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school
yard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance, or any other place for
the sale of merchandise, public accommodation or amusement.
(p)   "Registered mail" includes certified mail and "certified mail" includes
registered mail.
   (ORC 1.02(G))
(q)   "Rule" includes regulation. (ORC 1.59(F))
(r)   "Sidewalk" means that portion of the street between the curb line and the
adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
(s)   "This State" or "the State" means the State of Ohio.
   (ORC 1.59(G))
(t)   "Street" includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, highways,
viaducts and all other public thoroughfares within the Municipality.
(u)   "Tenant" or "occupant", as applied to premises, includes any person
holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part
of such premises, alone or with others.
(v)   "Whoever" includes all persons, natural and artificial; partners;
principals, agents and employees; and all officials, public or private.
   (ORC 1.02(A))
(w)   "Written" or "in writing" includes any representation of words, letters,
symbols or figures. This provision does not affect any law relating to
signatures.
      (ORC 1.59(J))
   101.03  RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   Common and Technical Usage. Words and phrases shall be read in context
and construed according to the rules of grammar and common usage. Words and
phrases that have acquired a technical or particular meaning, whether by
legislative definition or otherwise, shall be construed accordingly.
(ORC 1.42)
   (b)   Singular and Plural; Gender; Tense. As used in the Codified
Ordinances, unless the context otherwise requires:
(1)   The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the singular.
(2)   Words of one gender include the other genders.
(3)   Words in the present tense include the future.
         (ORC 1.43)
   (c)   Calendar; Computation of Time.
(1)   Definitions.
A.   "Week" means seven consecutive days.
B.   "Year" means twelve consecutive months.
            (ORC 1.44)
(2)   If a number of months is to be computed by counting the months from a
particular day, the period ends on the same numerical day in the concluding
month as the day of the month from which the computation is begun, unless there
are not that many days in the concluding month, in which case the period ends
on the last day of that month.
         (ORC 1.45)
      (3)   The time within which an act is required by law to be done shall be
computed by excluding the first and including the last day, except that when
the last day falls on Sunday or a legal holiday, then the act may be done on
the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a legal holiday.
         When a public office, in which an act required by law is to be
performed, is closed to the public for the entire day which constitutes the
last day for doing such act or before its usual closing time on such day, then
such act may be performed on the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a
legal holiday. If any legal holiday falls on Sunday, the next succeeding day is
a legal holiday.
         (ORC 1.14)
(4)   When legislation is to take effect or become operative from and after a
day named, no part of that day shall be included.
   (ORC 1.15)
(5)   In all cases where the law shall require any act to be done in a
reasonable time or reasonable notice to be given, such reasonable time or
notice shall mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance
of such duty or compliance with such notice.
   (d)   Authority. When the law requires an act to be done which may by law as
well be done by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be
construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent.
   (e)   Joint Authority. All words purporting to give joint authority to three
or more municipal officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such
authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it shall be
otherwise expressly declared in the law giving the authority or inconsistent
with State statute or Charter provisions.
   (f)   Exceptions. The rules of construction shall not apply to any law which
shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or when the
subject matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto.
   101.04  REVIVOR; EFFECT OF AMENDMENT OR REPEAL.
   (a)   The repeal of a repealing ordinance does not revive the ordinance
originally repealed nor impair the effect of any saving clause therein.
(ORC 1.57)
   (b)   An ordinance which is re-enacted or amended is intended to be a
continuation of the prior ordinance and not a new enactment, so far as it is
the same as the prior ordinance.
(ORC 1.54)
   (c)   The re-enactment, amendment or repeal of an ordinance does not, except
as provided in subsection (d) hereof:
(1)   Affect the prior operation of the ordinance or any prior action taken
thereunder;
(2)   Affect any validation, cure, right, privilege, obligation or liability
previously acquired, accrued, accorded or incurred thereunder;
(3)   Affect any violation thereof or penalty, forfeiture or punishment
incurred in respect thereto, prior to the amendment or repeal;
(4)   Affect any investigation, proceeding or remedy in respect of any such
privilege, obligation, liability, penalty, forfeiture or punishment; and the
investigation, proceeding or remedy may be instituted, continued or enforced,
and the penalty, forfeiture or punishment imposed, as if the ordinance had not
been repealed or amended.
   (d)   If the penalty, forfeiture or punishment for any offense is reduced by
a re-enactment or amendment of an ordinance, the penalty, forfeiture, or
punishment, if not already imposed, shall be imposed according to the ordinance
as amended.
(ORC 1.58)
   101.05  CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   (a)   A reference to any portion of the Codified Ordinances applies to all
re-enactments or amendments thereof.
(ORC 1.55)
   (b)   If a section refers to a series of numbers or letters, the first and
the last numbers or letters are included.
(ORC 1.56)
   (c)   Wherever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
series of sections or of subsections of a section, such reference shall be
construed to mean a violation of any section or subsection included in such
reference.
   References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized under
designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case, action
taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.23)
   101.06 CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   (a)   If there is a conflict between figures and words in expressing a
number, the words govern.
(ORC 1.46)
   (b)   If a general provision conflicts with a special or local provision,
they shall be construed, if possible, so that effect is given to both. If the
conflict between the provisions is irreconcilable, the special or local
provision prevails as an exception to the general provision, unless the general
provision is the later adoption and the manifest intent is that the general
provision prevail.
(ORC 1.51)
(c)   (1)   If ordinances enacted at different meetings of Council are
irreconcilable, the ordinance latest in date of enactment prevails.
(2)   If amendments to the same ordinance are enacted at different meetings of
Council, one amendment without reference to another, the amendments are to be
harmonized, if possible, so that effect may be given to each. If the amendments
are substantively irreconcilable, the latest in date of enactment prevails. The
fact that a later amendment restates language deleted by an earlier amendment,
or fails to include language inserted by an earlier amendment, does not of
itself make the amendments irreconcilable. Amendments are irreconcilable only
when changes made by each cannot reasonably be put into simultaneous operation.
         (ORC 1.52)
   101.07  DETERMINATION OF LEGISLATIVE INTENT.
   (a)   In enacting an ordinance, it is presumed that:
(1)   Compliance with the constitutions of the State and of the United States
is intended;
(2)   The entire ordinance is intended to be effective;
(3)   A just and reasonable result is intended;
(4)   A result feasible of execution is intended.
         (ORC 1.47)
   (b)   An ordinance is presumed to be prospective in its operation unless
expressly made retrospective.
(ORC 1.48)
   (c)   If an ordinance is ambiguous, the court, in determining the intention
of Council may consider among other matters:
(1)   The object sought to be attained;
(2)   The circumstances under which the ordinance was enacted;
(3)   The legislative history;
(4)   The common law or former legislative provisions, including laws upon the
same or similar subjects;
(5)   The consequences of a particular construction;
(6)   The administrative construction of the ordinance.
         (ORC 1.49)
   101.08  SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of a section of the Codified Ordinances or the application
thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not
affect the other provisions or applications of the section or related sections
which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to
this end the provisions are severable.
(ORC 1.50)
   101.99  GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the
Municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is
otherwise provided, whoever violates any such provision shall be punished by a
fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be
deemed committed each day during or on which a violation continues or occurs.

44 et seq.
         Oath of Office - see CHTR Sec.
80
         Open Meetings - see Ohio R.C. 121.22
   113.01 CLERK OF THE CITY COMMISSION.
   (a)   The Clerk of the City Commission shall keep a record of the
proceedings of the City Commission and perform such other duties as may be
prescribed by the Charter or by the City Commission.
   (b)   The Clerk shall be an executive secretary as provided for by ordinance
and paid accordingly. The City Manager shall designate the step in the pay
range.
   (c)   The Clerk shall be a full-time regular employee whose hours of work
per day and per week shall be the same as those generally set for clerical
employees of the City in the Department of City Manager and the Department of
Finance and Audits. All the applicable personnel regulations shall apply to the
Clerk.
(1980 Code 30.02)
   113.02  NOMINATING PETITIONS FOR THE OFFICE OF CITY COMMISSIONER.
   (a)   Petitions for nomination for the office of a member of the City
Commission of the City, and for placement upon the ballot as a candidate for
said office shall comply with the requirements of Article
46 of the Charter of the City; and each of the same shall contain and set forth
twenty-five numbered spaces for the insertion of the signatures, street and
number addresses, wards and precincts, and dates of signing as to the
signators;
   (b)   Such petitions shall be in a form prepared and provided by the Clerk
of the City Commission;
   (c)   As to completed petition forms which are submitted, no signature other
than those which properly appear in the twenty-five numbered spaces shall be
counted or included as valid signatures for the purpose of nomination and
placement upon the ballot as set forth in Article
46 of the Charter of the City, and only the twenty-five signatures properly
entered thereupon shall be counted and included for said purpose; and
   (d)   Nothing in this section shall, or shall be construed to invalidate any
signatures or petitions in relation to the November, 1995, general election
within the City, at which members of the City Commission of the City will be
elected.
(Ord. 95-134. Passed 7-24-95.)
   113.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For purposes of Sections
113.03 through
113.10, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings
ascribed to them respectively.
(a)   "Informal meeting" means a meeting of the City Commission where no formal
action of any kind is taken.
(b)   "Meeting" means any prearranged discussion of the public business of the
public body by a majority of its members.
(c)   "Public body" means the City Commission and any board, commission,
committee, or similar decision-making body of the City.
(d)   "Regular meeting" means a meeting of the City Commission where
communications are read and where resolutions, ordinances, or rules are adopted
or formal action of any kind is taken.
(e)   "Special meeting" means a regular meeting of the City Commission
specially called as hereinafter set forth.
   (1980 Code 30.10)
   113.04 MEETINGS OPEN TO PUBLIC; MINUTES TO BE AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC
INSPECTION.
   (a)   All meetings of any public body are declared to be public meetings
open to the public at all times, except for executive sessions as hereinafter
set forth.
   (b)   The minutes of a regular or special meeting of any such public body
shall be promptly recorded and open to public inspection. The minutes need only
reflect the general subject matter of discussions in executive sessions
authorized under Section
113.05.
(1980 Code 30.11)
   113.05  EXECUTIVE SESSIONS.
   The City Commission and other public bodies may hold executive sessions at
regular or special meetings for purposes as set forth in Ohio R.C. 121.22 as
now in effect or hereafter amended. Executive sessions are not open to the
public. (1980 Code 30.12)
   113.06 TIME AND PLACE OF FIRST MEETING OF COMMISSION FOLLOWING REGULAR
ELECTION.
   The City Commission shall meet on a date and time decided by a majority of
the Commission, following a regular municipal election, in the City Commission
Room of the City Building, at which time newly elected City Commissioners shall
assume the duties of their office for the purpose of electing a President and
Vice-President and conducting any other necessary business.
(Ord. 90-033. Passed 2-12-90.)
   113.07 REGULAR MEETINGS OF CITY COMMISSION.
   Effective January 1, 1997, and until modified or amended by a majority of
the City Commission, the Commission shall meet on the following basis:
(a)   Regular meetings of the Commission, except as hereinafter set forth,
shall be held on the second and fourth Monday of each month at 4:30 p.m. in the
City Commission Room of the City Building.
(b)   When the date of a regularly scheduled meeting falls on a holiday as
defined by ordinance, such meeting shall be held at 4:30 p.m. on the next
scheduled workday following the holiday.
(c)   The public shall be given the opportunity, when recognized by the
President, to speak at a regularly scheduled meeting for three minutes, only on
a topic being discussed by the Commission at that time. The public shall have
an additional opportunity to speak at the informal session following the
regularly scheduled meeting for five minutes on any topic over which the
Commission may have control.
(d)   On a quarterly basis, the Commission may conduct at least one of its
meetings outside of the City Building, at a site and time as set by a majority
vote of the Commission.
(e)   The Commission may schedule work sessions at the discretion of the
Commission when the work load, nature of an issue or issues, or other
circumstances may dictate.
(f)   The Commission shall adopt procedures for the regulation of meetings and
other business which may be modified from time to time by the Commission. Such
procedures shall be in writing and maintained by the Clerk of the Commission.
      (Ord. 96-231. Passed 12-9-96.)
   113.08 SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   Special meetings of the City Commission shall be held on call of the
President, any 2 members of the City Commission, or the City Manager, upon at
least 12 hours written notice to each member served personally or left at his
usual place of residence, or called for at a regular meeting provided such
written notice is given to any City Commissioner absent at the regular meeting.
Unless called at a regular meeting, agencies gathering and disseminating news
to the general public which are regularly represented at meetings of the City
Commission shall also be given notice of a special meeting. (Ord. 7901. Passed
12-1-75)
   113.09  INFORMAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   Informal meetings of the City Commission shall be held 1/2 hour before
regular meetings in the City Commission Room of the City Building and may be
held at any other time or place as called by the President, any 2 members of
the City Commission, or the City Manager, upon written notice given as set
forth in Section
113.08.
   (b)   Informal meetings may also be held immediately following any regular
or special meeting of the City Commission upon call by the President, 2 members
of the City Commission, or the City Manager. (Ord. 7901. Passed 12-1-75)
   113.10 RULES FOR IMPLEMENTING SECTIONS
113.03 THROUGH
113.09.
   Rules for the implementation of Sections
113.03 through
113.09, apply to the City Commission or any public body within the purview of
these sections; except that no public body may adopt rules in conflict with
rules adopted by the City Commission.
(Ord. 7901. Passed 12-1-75)

Administrative Organization

17 et seq.
   125.01 ORGANIZATION OF MUNICIPAL DEPARTMENTS.
   (a)   The organizational structure of all the City's departments shall
operate in accordance with the City's official organizational chart attached to
original Ordinance 96-098.
   (b)   The positions of Director of General Services, Director of Engineering
Services, Director of Public Services, Director of Community Development, and
the Utility Director shall report to and be directly responsible to the City
Manager. These department head positions shall be hired by the City Manager and
shall be retained based on each incumbent's job performance as determined by
the City Manager.
   (c)   The positions of Finance Director, Law Director and Commission Clerk
shall be hired and shall serve at the pleasure of the City Commission. Said
positions shall retain all rights and responsibilities and perform all of their
respective duties as set forth by the Charter of the City. Said positions shall
communicate with and work in concert with the City Manager and shall follow the
administrative and personnel regulations established for all employees of the
City. (Ord. 96-098. Passed 5-13-96.)
   125.02  DEPARTMENTS AND DIVISIONS.
   (a)   Departments and divisions of the City Government shall be as follows:
      (1)   Department of Finance and Audits.
         A.   Division of Taxation;
         B.   Division of Data Processing;
         C.   Division of Customer Accounting;
         D.   Division of Finance and Audits.
      (2)   Department of Law.
      (3)   Department of Municipal Court.
      (4)   Department of Public Services.
         A.   Division of Forestry;
         B.   Division of Parks;
         C.   Division of Recreation;
         D.   Division of Cemetery;
         E.   Division of Grounds Maintenance;
         F.   Division of Mechanics.
      (5)   Department of General Services.
         A.   Division of Police;
         B.   Division of Fire;
         C.   Division of Personnel and Risk Management.
      (6)   Department of Engineering Services.
         A.   Division of Engineering, Design, and Construction;
         B.   Division of Traffic Services.
         C.   Division of Building;
         D.   Division of Sewer Collections;
         E.   Division of Wastewater Treatment;
         F.   Division of Water Filtration;
         G.   Division of Water Distribution;
      (7)   Department of Community Development.
         A.   Division of Planning and Zoning;
         B.   Division of Housing and Neighborhood Development;
         C.   Division of Code Enforcement;
         D.   Division of Economic Development;
         E.   Division of Transit.
      (8)   City Manager's Office.
         A.   Administration;
         B.   Labor Relations;
         C.   Purchasing.
(Ord. 05-119. Passed 7-25-05.)
   125.03 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS FOR DEPARTMENTS.
   Each person holding the position of Director of Engineering Services,
Director of Community Development, Director of General Services, Director of
Public Service, Utility Director, Office Manager - Division of Finance and
Audits, Income Tax Administrator, Purchasing Agent, Big Island Water Works
Superintendent, Water Pollution Control Plant Superintendent, Street
Superintendent, Housing and Nuisance Control Coordinator, Grounds Maintenance
Superintendent, Forestry Superintendent, Parks Superintendent, City Mechanic,
Recreation Director, and Municipal Court Clerk, as such positions are presently
described or as may be modified from time to time as to duties, shall become
and continue to be a resident and qualified elector of the City within a
reasonable time, as set by the City Commission, of their respective
appointment.
   This section shall not apply to those persons who held any of said positions
as of January 22, 1990, and who continue their incumbency and service as to the
same who are not now residents of the City, or to persons who occupied
positions of assistant to any position listed above who were promoted to the
same between January 22, 1990, and January 23, 1995. However, if any such
person should change his or her residence at any time hereafter, he or she then
shall be required to comply with this section, and to establish, and to
continue his or her residence within the City of Sandusky, Ohio. (Ord. 95-119.
Passed 6-26-95.)
CHAPTER 127

   127.01  CITY MANAGER'S POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The City Manager shall be the administrative head of the municipal
government under the direction and supervision of the City Commission and shall
hold office at the pleasure of the City Commission and shall have the powers
and duties as set forth in the Charter of the City and the state laws; he is
designated as Safety Director to perform all duties required of a Safety
Director by the State Civil Service laws; he shall have all powers conferred
upon safety directors and service directors by the state laws.
(Ord. 05-157. Passed 10-24-05.)
   127.02  ASSISTANT CITY MANAGER.
   The Assistant City Manager shall be appointed by the City Manager, with the
consent of the City Commission, and shall have such duties as are assigned to
him by the City Manager and may represent the City Manager in any of the
departments or divisions of the City Government of which the City Manager is
the head.
(Ord. 05-157. Passed 10-24-05.)
   127.03 DIVISION OF POLICE.
   (a)   The Division of Police shall be headed by the Chief of Police and
shall be composed of the following officers and other members of the classified
service, who shall be classified and paid according to the provisions of
Chapter
145 unless otherwise provided by ordinance or by the Charter of the City:
Chief, Assistant Chief, Captains, Lieutenants, Sergeants and police officers.
The duties and functions of the Department and the number and duties of the
various classes of officers and employees shall be determined by the City
Manager in consultation with the Chief of Police and the City Commission as
provided in the City Charter.
   (b)   Each police officer in the Division of Police shall be designated as a
Class A police officer or Class B police officer. A Class A police officer is
one who has completed not less than five years of service in the Division of
Police, whether such service was continuous or otherwise; and a Class B police
officer is one who has completed not more than five years of service in the
Division of Police, whether such service was continuous or otherwise.
   (c)   In the event, however, that a vacancy occurs in the Division of
Police, by death, retirement, resignation, promotion or otherwise, which
reduces the total strength of said Division, and it is impossible or
impractical for any reason for said vacancy to be filled immediately or without
delay, the City Manager is authorized and empowered to appoint pursuant to the
civil service regulations of the City, an additional police officer to a
position and the Division of Police shall operate with such additional position
until such time as promotional advancement steps may be taken as required by
such vacancy.
(Ord. 05-157. Passed 10-24-05.)
   127.04 PRIVATE POLICE.
   (a)   When any person, firm, or corporation having a place of business or
controlling or owning any personal property or real estate within the corporate
limits of the City shall request for the better protection of business property
the appointment of one or more additional police officers, it shall be the duty
of the City Manager to appoint such police officers that he deems suitable
persons for such position. Such police officers shall be duly commissioned by
the City Manager and shall constitute members of the private police force of
the City. No provision of this section shall be construed as affecting the
regular classification list of the Division of Police.
   (b)   The members of the private police force of the City shall have the
same powers and be subject to the same regulations as other police officers.
They shall perform such police duties at such place or places within the City
limits as the person, firm, or corporation requesting their appointment may
direct; however, such duties shall not be contrary to or inconsistent with the
laws or the City ordinances.
   (c)   Each member of the private police force shall serve during the
pleasure of the person, firm, or corporation requesting his appointment. Each
member shall be paid by the person, firm or corporation requesting his
appointment such compensation as may be agreed upon between him and the person,
firm, or corporation.
   (d)   Qualifications of Members. All members shall be citizens of the United
States, residents of the State, not under twenty-one years of age at the time
of appointment, in good health and of good moral character. Additionally, each
member shall have been awarded a certificate by the executive director of the
Ohio Peace Officers Training Council attesting to his satisfactory completion
of the prescribed basic course of training and that he is qualified as an Ohio
peace officer, or ne may be conditionally commissioned by the City Manager to
attend such police school, but in any event, he must be awarded a certificate
as an Ohio peace officer within one year of his appointment. (Ord. 05-157.
Passed 10-24-05.)
   127.05 SPECIAL POLICE.
   (a)   There shall be employed in the Division of Police such number of
special police as may be required. Special police shall serve at the pleasure
of the City Manager and shall have such duties as he assigns to them. No
provision of this section shall be construed as affecting the regular
classification list of the Division of Police.
   (b)   Qualifications of Members. All members shall be citizens of the United
States, residents of the State, not under twenty-one years of age at the time
of appointment, in good health and of good moral character. Additionally, each
member shall have been awarded a certificate by the Executive Director of the
Ohio Peace Officers Training Council attesting to his satisfactory completion
of the prescribed basic course of training and that he is qualified as an Ohio
peace officer, or he may be conditionally commissioned by the City Manager to
attend such police school, but in any event he must be awarded a certificate as
an Ohio peace officer within one year of his appointment.
(Ord. 05-157. Passed 10-24-05.)
   127.06  RESERVE POLICE UNIT.
   (a)   General Provisions. There is created a Reserve Unit within the
Division of Police, the members of which shall be appointed by the City
Manager. Each Reserve Officer shall serve at the pleasure of the City Manager
or until the resignation of such Reserve Officer is accepted by the City
manager, and during good behavior and faithful service; but any such officer
may be removed for incompetency, discourteous treatment of the public, neglect
of duty, failure to obey orders, failure to abide by the rules and regulations
for the Reserve Unit, or any other acts of misfeasance, malfeasance or
nonfeasance in office, as determined by the City Manager.
   (b)   Membership Selection Committee. A Membership Selection Committee
composed of the City Manager or his designee, the Chief of Police and the
designated head of the Reserve Unit shall review all applications for
membership and determine the suitability of each applicant. Appointment of the
applicant shall be by unanimous approval of the Selection Committee.
   (c)   Classification of Members. Members of the Reserve Unit shall be
classified and have authority as follows:
      (1)   Commissioned reservists. These members shall be commissioned as
special police officers of the City and shall be responsible to enforce the
general laws of the State and ordinances of the City, and may be empowered to
carry firearms.
      (2)   Reservists. These members shall not be commissioned as special
police officers, shall not be granted police powers and shall not carry
firearms. However, they shall assist commissioned reservists and officers in
the Division of Police.
      (3)   Cadet reservist. These members shall not be commissioned as special
police officers, shall not be granted police powers and shall not carry
firearms. However, they shall assist commissioned and noncommissioned
reservists and officers in the Division of Police. Cadet reservists may not be
appointed a commissioned or noncommissioned reserve until attaining twenty-one
years of age.
   (d)   Qualifications of Members. All members of the Reserve Unit shall be
citizens of the United States, residents of the State, not under twenty-one
years of age if a commissioned or noncommissioned reservist and not under
twenty years of age if a cadet reservist, at the time of appointment, in good
health and of good moral character. Additionally, a commissioned reservist
shall have been awarded a certificate by the executive director of the Ohio
Peace Officers Training Council attesting to his satisfactory completion of the
prescribed basic course of training and that he is qualified as an Ohio peace
officer, or he may be conditionally commissioned by the City Manager to attend
such police school, but in any event he must be awarded a certificate as an
Ohio peace officer within one year of his appointment to the Reserve Unit. All
members shall also comply with all other requirements of the rules and
regulations of the Reserve Unit.
   (e)   Control of Unit. The Chief of Police or his designated representative
shall be commanding officer of the Reserve Unit and shall be responsible for
the assigning, training, stationing and directing of the work of such Unit. All
Reserve Unit members shall obey the chain of command of the Police division and
shall be subordinate to all regular appointed members thereof.
   (f)   Rules and Regulations. The City Manager shall approve in writing the
rules and regulations for the organization, administration, conduct and control
of the Reserve Unit, not in conflict with the provisions of the Ohio Revised
Code or this section.
   (g)   Uniforms. The rules and regulations shall prescribe the type of
uniform which shall be worn by the members of the Reserve Unit and the time and
place such uniforms shall be worn. The cost of these uniforms shall be paid by
the City and shall remain the property of the City.
   (h)   Compensation. The City Manager is authorized to approve payment for
members of the Reserve unit from a minimum of eight dollars ($8.00) per hour to
a maximum of twelve dollars ($12.00) per hour for each hour of duty assigned by
the Chief of Police or his designated representative. Compensation shall not be
paid for any hours which are not specifically ordered by the Chief of Police or
his designated representative. The hourly compensation shall not exceed the
current hourly rate authorized by the operating budget for the applicable year.
A member may waive, in writing, any rights to monetary compensation for all or
part of the hours for which the member may be entitled to compensation.
(Ord. 05-157. Passed 10-24-05.)
   127.07 PARKING REGULATORS.
   At the direction of the City Manager, the Chief of Police, from time to
time, may hire and employ, for such duration and under such terms as the City
Manager deems appropriate, as uncommissioned employees of the City, one or more
parking regulators who shall monitor, and enforce the parking ordinances,
regulations, and restrictions of the City, and who are authorized to issue
citations and notices as to violations of the same.
(Ord. 05-157. Passed 10-24-05.)
   127.08 DIVISION OF FIRE.
   The Division of Fire shall be headed by the Fire Chief and shall be composed
of the following officers and other members in the classified civil service,
who shall be classified and paid according to the provisions of Chapter
145 unless otherwise provided for by ordinance: Chief, Assistant Chiefs,
Battalion Chiefs, Captains, Lieutenants and Firefighters. The duties and
functions of the department and the number and duties of the various classes of
officers and employees shall be determined by the City Manager in consultation
with the Fire Chief and th City Commission as provided in the City Charter.
(Ord. 05-157. Passed 10-24-05.)
   127.09 CLASSIFICATIONS IN THE DIVISION OF FIRE.
   Each firefighter in the Division of Fire shall be designated as Class A
firefighter, Class B firefighter, or Class C firefighter. A Class A firefighter
is one who has completed not less than two years of service in the Division of
Fire, whether such service was continuous or otherwise; a Class B firefighter
is one who has completed one year of service in the Division of Fire and not
more than two years of service whether such service was continuous or
otherwise; a Class C firefighter is one who has completed less than one year of
service in the Division of Fire.
(Ord. 05-157. Passed 10-24-05.)
   127.10  FIREFIGHTER/PARAMEDICS.
   (a)   All Fire Department personnel hired on or after September 1, 1989,
shall be hired as Firefighter/Paramedics and such personnel shall be required
to obtain and maintain certification as an Emergency Medical Technician-
Paramedic, in addition to the requirements mandated to become a qualified
firefighter.
   (b)   Notwithstanding the above, rules shall be established by the Fire
Chief, subject to the approval of the City Manager, which shall identify
minimum and maximum Paramedic staffing required by the Department, the length
of active Paramedic service required, participation, and compliance to training
and recertification requirements. When such staffing requirements are met, the
Fire Chief shall be empowered to temporarily waive the requirement set forth in
subsection (a) hereof for all new and existing employees hired after September
1, 1989, and may renew such a waiver based on the needs of the Department.
(Ord. 05-157. Passed 10-24-05.)
CHAPTER 129
Department of Finance and Audits
129.01   General provisions.
129.02   Division of Taxation.
129.03   Division of Data Processing.
129.04   Division of Customer Accounting.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Department of Finance and Audits - see CHTR. Sec.
18     et seq.
      Residency requirement - se CHTR. Sec.
86.
   129.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (a)   Offices.  The Department of Finance and Audits shall be headed by the
Finance Director. He shall hold office at the pleasure of the City Commission
and shall have the powers and duties set forth in the Charter of the City and
State laws. The Finance Director with the approval of the City Commission may
appoint a Deputy Finance Director to assist him or her in performance of his or
her duties. The Finance Director also may appoint from those persons employed
by the Department of Finance and Audits an Assistant Finance Director who shall
perform such duties as are assigned by the Finance Director and are not
inconsistent with the provisions of the Charter of the City.
   (b)   Investment of Funds. Whenever there are moneys in the treasury of the
City which will not be required to be used for a period of 6 months or more,
such moneys may, in lieu of being deposited in a bank or banks, be invested in
accordance with the provisions of Ohio R.C. 731.56 through 731.59. Investments
so purchased shall be sold in accordance with Ohio R.C. 731.57.
   (c)   Allocation of Interest and Income.  The Director of Finance is
empowered to allocate the interest and/or income earned on the moneys of the
City among the various funds of the City, and from time to time to designate to
which fund or funds, and in what amounts the same will be credited. (Ord. 91-
123. Passed 9-23-91.)
   129.02 DIVISION OF TAXATION.
   The Division of Taxation shall have the administration of the income tax
ordinance as its primary duty, but shall have such other duties and functions
as are determined by the Finance Director or by ordinance. (Ord. 6649-C. Passed
12-4-67.)
   129.03  DIVISION OF DATA PROCESSING.
   The Division of Data Processing shall be headed by the Data Processing
Manager who shall be appointed by the Finance Director. The Data Processing
Manager shall be responsible for implementing and administering the City's data
processing program in accordance with the policies and priorities promulgated
by the Finance Director and confirmed by the City Manager.
(1980 Code 32.03)
   129.04  DIVISION OF CUSTOMER ACCOUNTING.
   The Division of Customer Accounting shall be headed by the cashier who shall
also be known as the office manager. The Division of Customer Accounting shall
be responsible for those duties appropriately assigned to it by the Finance
Director pursuant to Charter Sec.
20 or as may be provided for by ordinance.
(1980 Code 32.09)
CHAPTER 131
Department of Law
131.01   General provisions.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Law Director - see CHTR. Sec.
17
      Residency requirement - see CHTR. Sec.
86
      Statutory powers and duties - see Ohio R.C. 733.51 et seq.
   131.01  GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   The Department of Law shall be headed by the Law Director who shall hold
office at the pleasure of the City Commission and who shall act as the legal
advisor to, and attorney and counsel for, the Municipality and all its officers
in the Municipality and all its officers in matters relating to their official
duties, and who shall have the powers and duties as set forth in the Charter of
the City and the State laws. There shall also be such number of Assistant Law
Directors as may be authorized by the City Commission and who shall serve at
the pleasure of the City Commission.
   The Law Director and the Assistant Law Director shall be hired and employed
on a part-time basis.
(Ord. 88-127. Passed 10-17-88.)

      Record of traffic violations - see Ohio R.C. 4513.37
   133.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   The Municipal Court shall be headed by the municipal judge who shall have
all the powers and duties given him by law. The Municipal Judge shall be paid
an annual salary as provided by state statute. (Ord. 6657. Passed 1-2-68.)
CHAPTER 135
Consumer Protection
135.01   Compliance with prevailing wage requirements.
135.02   Authority of Prevailing Wage Coordinator to conduct investigations.
135.03    Compliance with chapter.
135.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Division of Consumer Finance - see Ohio R.C. 121.08
      Retail installment sales - see Ohio R.C. 1317.01
      Special account - see Ohio R.C. 1321.21
      Consumer sales practices - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1345
      Consumers’ cooperatives - see Ohio R.C. 1729.28
      Consumers’ counsel - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4911
   135.01 COMPLIANCE WITH PREVAILING WAGE REQUIREMENTS.
   No person doing business within the City and holding himself, herself or
itself out to the public, by advertising himself, herself or itself to the
public, as complying with the prevailing wage law requirements, as those
requirements are defined in Ohio R.C. Chapter 4115 et seq., shall advertise
his, her or its services or perform any services within the City on work
subject to the prevailing wage law, unless the prevailing wages are paid. All
employees performing work as apprentices on prevailing wage work must be either
participants in or graduates of a bona fide apprentice training program.
(Ord. 07-020. Passed 4-23-07.)
   135.02 AUTHORITY OF PREVAILING WAGE COORDINATOR TO CONDUCT INVESTIGATIONS.
   The Prevailing Wage Coordinator for the City is authorized to conduct
investigations upon receipt of complaints relating to any provisions in this
chapter, and may refer any related matter to the office of the Law Director.
(Ord. 07-020. Passed 4-23-07.)
   135.03 COMPLIANCE WITH CHAPTER.
   Each person who or which desires to perform construction work within the
City, which construction work customarily involves the services of persons in
the skilled trades, including, but not limited to, plumbers, carpenters,
bricklayers, ironworkers, glaziers, painters and electricians, shall as a pre-
condition for working within the City on any work reasonably valued in excess
of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) for the entire project, regardless of the
individual’s subcontractor(s), shall comply with this chapter. Further, as a
condition for performing prevailing wage work in the City, each individual or
firm shall respond to any and all requests of the Prevailing Wage Coordinator
for information bearing on the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 07-020. Passed 4-23-07.)
   135.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each
willful offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which the violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 07-020. Passed 4-23-07.)

CHAPTER 141
Professional Design Services Selection
141.01   Definitions.
141.02   Prequalification.
141.03   Statement of qualifications.
141.04   Pre-design and announcement.
141.05   Selection process.
141.06   Liability insurance.
141.07   Exemptions.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Sewer regulations and rates - see S.U.&P.S. Ch.
933
      Water regulations and rates - see S.U.&P.S. Ch.
939
   141.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   (a)   The definitions set forth in Ohio R.C. 153.65 are incorporated in this
chapter by reference.
   (b)   “City” means the City of Sandusky.
   (c)   “Professional design firm” means any person legally engaged in
rendering professional design services.
   (d)   “Professional design services” means services within the scope of
practice of an architect or landscape architect registered under Ohio R.C.
Chapter 4703 or a professional engineer or surveyor registered under Ohio R.C.
Chapter 4733.
   (e)   “Qualifications” means all of the following:
      (1)   Competence of the professional design firm to perform with the
required professional design services as indicated by the technical training,
education and experience of the firm’s personnel, especially the technical
training, education and experience of the employees within the firm who would
be assigned to perform the services;
      (2)   Ability of the firm in terms of its workload and the availability
of qualified personnel, equipment and facilities to perform the required
professional design services competently and expeditiously;
      (3)   Past performance of the firm as reflected by the evaluations of
previous clients with respect to such factors as control of costs, quality of
work, and meeting of deadlines;
      (4)   Any other relevant factors as determined by the City.
         (Ord. 05-119. Passed 7-25-05.)
   141.02  PREQUALIFICATION.
   (a)   The City Manager may adopt prequalification requirements for
professional design firms seeking to provide professional design services to
the City. The prequalification requirements shall require each prequalified
firm to maintain a current statement of qualifications on file with the
Department of Engineering Services.
   (b)   The prequalification requirements shall be based on:
      (1)   Past performance and current performance on City, state and other
contracts; and
      (2)   The qualifications of the professional design firm.
   (c)   Professional design firms that are prequalified must comply with all
requirements of this section, including the ranking of qualified firms based on
the specific work sought by the City.
(Ord. 05-119. Passed 7-25-05.)
   141.03  STATEMENT OF QUALIFICATIONS.
   (a)   Professional design firms are encouraged to submit a statement of
qualifications to the City at any time by filing with the Department of
Engineering Services. Professional design firms are required to regularly
update information contained in statements of qualifications submitted to the
City in order to provide current information. The Director of Engineering
Services shall establish procedures for receiving and maintaining statements of
qualifications of professional design firms.
   (b)   Each professional design firm shall update its statement of
qualifications not less than once each calendar year.
   (c)   Statements of qualifications of professional design firms on file
which are not current shall not be reviewed and evaluated.
(Ord. 05-119. Passed 7-25-05.)
   141.04  PRE-DESIGN AND ANNOUNCEMENT.
   (a)   Unless waived by the City Manager, the Director of Engineering
Services shall provide or cause to be provided pre-design and programming
services for a project before issuing any announcement for any contract for
professional design services for the project. The pre- design and programming
services shall provide preliminary information and options about scope of work
and other project requirements such as soil boring, geotechnical and
environmental testing and other testing, inspection and analysis, the schedule,
the conceptual design and the budget.
   (b)   Upon completion of the pre-design and programming services, the
Director of Engineering Services, with the consent of the City Manager, shall
publicly announce all contracts for professional design services for the
project.
      (1)   Announcements shall be made in a uniform and consistent manner in
advance of the time that responses are to be received.
      (2)   An announcement shall include a general description of the project,
a statement of the specific professional design services required, and a
description of the qualifications required for the project.
      (3)   An announcement shall indicate how a qualified professional design
firm may submit a statement of qualifications in order to be considered for a
contract for professional design services for the project.
      (4)   An announcement may request information about a professional design
firm’s previous projects, including fees, budgets and costs.
      (5)   An announcement shall be sent to either or both of the following in
the discretion of the Director of Engineering Services:
         A.   Each professional design firm that has a current statement of
qualifications on file and is qualified to perform the required, professional
design services as determined by the Director of Engineering Services.
         B.   Architect, landscape architect, engineer and surveyor trade
associations, the news media, and any publications or other public media deemed
appropriate by the Director of Engineering Services.
      (6)   An announcement may include any of the following:
The announcement can be in the form of an advertisement; such advertisement
shall include the following:
         A.   Proposed requests for design services, with a description of the
project, a statement of the specific professional design services required, and
a description of the qualifications required for the project;
         B.   For each design services project, the list of firms selected
pursuant to Section
141.05(c);
         C.   Notice of intent to award or of execution of contracts for
professional design services, including fees; and
         D.   Notice of intent to award or execution of construction contracts.
            (Ord. 05-119. Passed 7-25-05.)
   141.05 SELECTION PROCESS.
    (a)   The City Manager shall appoint a committee of three individuals, one
of whom shall be the Director of Engineering Services, to review and evaluate
statements of qualifications for each project. The committee shall review all
statements of qualifications on file with the Department of Engineering
Services and any statements of qualifications received by the City in response
to the announcement for the project from professional design firms qualified to
perform the required professional design services as determined by the Director
of Engineering Services. No professional design firm shall contact any member
of the committee about any project the firm desires to obtain except as
provided in this division.
   (b)   Based on the committee’s review and evaluation of the applicable
statements of qualifications, the committee shall rank the three professional
design firms that the committee determines to be most qualified. If fewer than
three firms submit statements of qualifications, the committee shall rank those
firms, issue a new announcement for the project or suspend or abandon the
project.
   (c)   The committee shall invite the three firms ranked most qualified to a
scope clarification meeting to explore the scope and nature of the services
required, the various technical approaches the firms may take toward the
project, the project requirements, the project schedule, the conceptual design
and the project budget. The meeting may include a visit to any proposed project
site. Any questions must be either resolved at the scope clarification meeting
and the resolution shared with all three firms or after the meeting by written
notice from the Director of Engineering Services to all three firms.
   (d)   The three firms shall supplement their statement of qualifications
with a technical proposal based upon the scope of services and project
requirements as clarified at the scope clarification meeting.
   (e)   The technical proposal shall be submitted to the Department of
Engineering Services by 5:00 p.m. on the 7th day after the scope clarification
meeting unless the Director of Engineering Services notifies all three firms of
a different place, time or date in writing.
   (f)   The Committee shall review the technical proposals and schedule
interviews with all three firms within seven days of receipt of the technical
proposals unless the Director of Engineering Services notifies all three firms
of a different period.
   (g)   The Committee shall evaluate, and rank the firms which were
interviewed in order of their qualifications and technical proposals.
   (h)   The Director of Engineering Services shall commence negotiations by
requesting a lump sum fee proposal from the firm ranked most qualified to
perform the required services.
   (i)   Upon receipt of the lump sum fee proposal, contract negotiations shall
be directed toward:
      (1)   Ensuring that the professional design firm and the City have a
mutual understanding of the essential requirements involved in providing the
required services, including meeting estimated project budget and schedule
requirements;
      (2)   Determining that the firm will make available the necessary
personnel, equipment and facilities to perform the services within the required
time;
      (3)   Agreeing upon compensation which is fair and reasonable, taking
into account the estimated value, scope, complexity and nature of the services.
   (j)   Upon negotiation of a contract with the firm ranked most qualified,
the Director of Engineering Services shall submit a request to the City
Commission for approval.
   (k)   Upon failure to negotiate a contract with the firm ranked most
qualified, the Director of Engineering Services shall inform the firm, in
writing, of the termination of negotiations. Negotiations shall be commenced
with the firm ranked next most qualified. If negotiations again fail, the same
procedure shall be followed with the third most qualified firm as ranked
pursuant to paragraph (g) of this division until a contract is negotiated or
negotiations with all such firms are terminated.
   (l)   If no contract is negotiated with any of the firms selected pursuant
to paragraph (k) of this division, additional firms may be ranked in accordance
with paragraph (b) of this division from firms whose qualification statements
were reviewed and evaluated under paragraph (a) of this division, a new
announcement may be issued for the project in accordance with Section
141.04 or the project may be suspended or abandoned.
(Ord. 05-119. Passed 7-25-05.)
   141.06  LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   (a)   Prior to executing a contract pursuant to this chapter, a professional
design firm shall present satisfactory evidence of professional liability
insurance for professional design services to the Director of Engineering
Services. The insurance shall be in an amount considered sufficient by the
Director of Engineering Services.
   (b)   The requirement for professional liability insurance may be waived at
the discretion of the City Manager.
(Ord. 05-119. Passed 7-25-05.)
   141.07  EXEMPTIONS.
   This chapter does not apply to either of the following:
   (a)   Any project with an estimated fee for professional design services of
less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000).
   (b)   Any project determined by the Director of Engineering Services or the
City Manager to be an emergency requiring immediate action including, but not
limited to, any projects requiring multiple contracts awarded as a part of a
program requiring a large number of professional design firms of the same type.
      (Ord. 05-119. Passed 7-25-05.)

   143.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   The Department of Community Development shall be headed by the Director of
Community Development who shall be appointed by and accountable to the City
Manager. The Department of Community Development shall consist of the Planning
and Zoning Division, Housing and Neighborhood Development Division, Code
Enforcement Division, Economic Development Division, and the Transit Division.
The duties and functions of the Department, its Divisions, and the duties of
the various classes of officers and employees therein shall be as provided for
by ordinance, by law and as determined by the City Manager.
(Ord. 05-119. Passed 7-25-05.)
   143.02  DIVISIONS WITHIN DEPARTMENT.
   (a)   Division of Planning and Zoning. The Division of Planning and Zoning
shall be headed by the Chief Planner who shall oversee planning and zoning
activities for the City.
   (b)   Division of Housing and Neighborhood Development. The Division of
Housing and Neighborhood Development shall be headed by the Community
Development Program Administrator who shall oversee all housing and
neighborhood development activities.
   (c)   Division of Code Enforcement. The Division of Code Enforcement shall
be headed by the Director of Community Development.
   (d)   Division of Economic Development. The Division of Economic Development
shall be headed by the Director of Community Development.
   (e)   Division of Transit. The Division of Transit shall be headed by the
Transit Administrator who shall oversee all transit activities.
(Ord. 05-119. Passed 7-25-05.)
   143.03  LAND REUTILIZATION - ADOPTION AND IMPLEMENTATION.
   (a)   The City of Sandusky hereby adopts and implements the procedures set
forth in Ohio R.C. Chapter 5722, known as Land Reutilization Program and the
provisions thereof.
   (b)   The City Commission finds and declares that there exists sufficient
and substantial nonproductive land within its boundaries as defined in Section
5722.01 of the Ohio Revised Code which is of such nature and extent as to
necessitate the implementation of a Land Reutilization Program to foster either
the return of such nonproductive land to tax revenue generating status or the
devotion thereof to public use.
   (c)   The City hereby agrees to implement and abide by the provisions of
Ohio R.C. Chapter 5722 currently in effect and as may be amended, for a Land
Reutilization Program as therein provided.
   (d)   The Clerk of the City Commission is hereby authorized and directed to
transmit certified copies of this section to the Erie County Auditor,
Treasurer, and Prosecutor as provided in Ohio R.C. 5722.02.
(Ord. 07-026. Passed 6-11-07.)
