convicted of a crime, misdemeanor, or the violation of any municipal ordinance,
the nature of the offense, and the punishment assessed therefore.
(l)   Credentials from the person, firm, or corporation for which the applicant
proposed to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such
representative.   
(Ord. 95-227. Passed 12-11-95.)
   741.04 LICENSE FEE.
   A nonrefundable fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be paid upon application
for a solicitor's license. If a solicitor's license is granted by the City
Manager, an additional fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid for
each person, other than the applicant, who shall solicit within the City under
the authority of such solicitor's license. In the case of sales from a vehicle,
the fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall apply to each such vehicle.
(Ord. 95-227. Passed 12-11-95.)
   741.05 EXPIRATION OF LICENSE.
   Solicitor licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire
one year after the date of issuance thereof unless a prior date is set therein.
(Ord. 95-227. Passed 12-11-95.)
   741.06  REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (a)   The licenses issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked at any
time by the City Manager, or his/her duly authorized representative, for any of
the following causes:
(1)   Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application for a license;
(2)   Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with
the selling of goods, wares, merchandise, or services;
(3)   Any violation of this chapter;
(4)   Conviction of the applicant or other persons acting under the authority
of the applicant's license of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral
turpitude;
(5)   Conducting the business permitted under this chapter in an unlawful
manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to
constitute a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the public; or
(6)   A verified complaint from a property owner that the applicant has
solicited where a "No Solicitation" sign has been posted.
   (b)   Within three working days of the revocation of a license, the City
Manager shall send notice to the person whose license has been revoked, setting
forth specifically the grounds of the revocation. Such notice shall be mailed
to the person to whom the license was issued at the address shown on the
license application. (Ord. 95-227. Passed 12-11-95.)
   741.07 DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   Every solicitor, while engaged in soliciting within the City, shall have in
his immediate possession the solicitor's license issued to him under the
provisions of this chapter, and where so soliciting shall display the same upon
demand of any person to whom he is soliciting.
(Ord. 95-227. Passed 12-11-95.)
   741.08 PROHIBITED CONDUCT WHEN SOLICITING FROM VEHICLE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person traveling about the City engaged in
soliciting from a vehicle to:
(a)   Operate a vehicle when under the age of eighteen years.
(b)   Operate a vehicle at a speed in excess of fifteen miles per hour or more
when cruising neighborhoods or attempting to make a sale.
(c)   Make a U-turn on any street.
(d)   Operate the vehicle backwards in making or attempting to make a sale.
(e)   Double park or park in any manner contrary to any ordinance relating to
parking when attempting to make or making a sale.
(f)   Permit any person, except an employee, to hang on the vehicle or permit
any person, except an employee, to ride in or on the vehicle.
(g)   Refuse to remove the vehicle from any street or public place in the City
upon the request of a police officer when, in the opinion of the police
officer, said vehicle is causing traffic congestion.
(h)   Make or attempt to make a sale within a public park, or within 500 feet
of any school, school yard or school playground during the hours when such
school is in regular or special session, or for a period of one-half hour after
the closing of such school.
(i)   Make or attempt to make a sale within 100 feet of an intersection.
(j)   Make or attempt to make a sale to any person standing in a street of the
City.
(k)   Make or attempt to make a sale from a side of a vehicle not closest to
the nearest curb or berm.
(l)   Cry his wares in a loud voice or use any noise-producing device other
than a soft chime, and the limit of audibility of his voice or chime shall not
be more than fifty feet from the source of such sound.
(m)   Sell or offer for sale, food, candy confection, frozen desserts or
beverages unless the operator of the vehicle, is at all times, accompanied by a
responsible adult whose sole duty it shall be to keep a look out for, and
protect the safety of, children and other persons attracted to or proceeding to
or from the location of the vehicle.
(n)   Make or attempt to make a sale on any City street designated by ordinance
or resolution as a truck route. (See Section
339.02.)
(o)   Sell or offer for sale food, candy confections, frozen desserts, or
beverages without first obtaining the proper licenses and inspections from the
Health Department.
(p)   Make or attempt to make a sale from any vehicle which does not have a
valid Ohio State Highway Patrol inspection sticker affixed to said vehicle's
front windshield.
(q)   Make or attempt to make a sale from any vehicle which does not have its
headlights lighted.
(r)   Make or attempt to make a sale from any vehicle which is not equipped
with a flashing signal lamp mounted on the roof of said vehicle. The driver of
the vehicle shall actuate the flashing signal lamp when stopped on the streets
for the purpose of vending. (Ord. 95-227. Passed 12-11-95.)
   741.09  HOURS OF BUSINESS.
   Persons may engage in soliciting between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 9:00
p.m.
(Ord. 95-227. Passed 12-11-95.)
   741.10 EXEMPTIONS.
   The following additional persons shall be exempted from the requirements of
this chapter: persons selling newspapers, commercial travelers or selling
agents calling upon commercial establishments in the usual course of business.
(Ord. 95-227. Passed 12-11-95.)
   741.11 ENFORCEMENT.
   The Chief of Police and his or her duly authorized representatives shall
have the authority to examine all places of business and persons within the
City subject to the provisions of this chapter, to determine if this chapter
has been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against
any person found to be violating the same.
(Ord. 95-227. Passed 12-11-95.)
   741.99  PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two
hundred dollars ($200.00), or imprisoned not more than thirty days, or both.
Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 95-227. Passed 12-11-95.)
                                                                                                  
CHAPTER 747
Public Vehicle for Hire

   Chauffeur defined, chauffeur’s license not required for taxicab driver - see
Ohio R.C. 4501.01(y)
   Chauffeured limousine defined - see Ohio R.C. 4501.01(LL)
   Chauffeured limousines, issuance of certificates of registration and license
plates or validation stickers - see Ohio R.C. 4503.19
   Chauffeured limousine, registration, plates, livery sticker - see Ohio R.C.
4503.24
   Bus defined - see Ohio R.C. 4501.01(I)
   Commercial motor vehicle defined - see Ohio R.C. 4506.01
   Commercial drivers license required - see Ohio R.C. 4506.03
   Operation of taxicab by minor prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 4507.321
   Chauffeured limousines, proof of financial responsibility - see Ohio R.C.

   Chauffeured limousines, cruising for patronage prohibited - see Ohio R.C.
4511.85
   Private motor carrier does not include taxicabs - see Ohio R.C. 4923.02(A)
(3)
   Occupant restraining devices for taxicab - see Ohio R.C. 4513.263(B)(4)
   Open container law - see Ohio R.C. 4301.62
   Consuming beer or intoxicating liquor in a motor vehicle - see Ohio R.C.
4301.64
   747.01 DEFINITIONS.
   Unless otherwise expressly stated, when used in this chapter, the following
terms shall be defined as follows:
   (a)   “Chauffeur” has the same meaning as contained in the Ohio R.C. 4501.01
(Y).
   (b)   “Chauffeured limousine” means a motor vehicle that is designed to
carry not more than fifteen passengers including the driver and is operated for
hire on an hourly basis pursuant to a prearranged contract for the
transportation of passengers on public roads and highways along a route under
the control of the person hiring the vehicle and not over a defined and regular
route. “Prearranged contract” means an agreement, made in advance of boarding,
to provide transportation from a specific location in a chauffeured limousine
at a fixed rate per hour or trip. “Chauffeured limousine” does not include any
vehicle that is used exclusively in the business of funeral directing.
      (O.R.C. 4501.01(LL))
   (c)   “Public vehicle for hire” means any vehicle which uses the public
streets for the transportation of persons under expectation of compensation or
reward in any form, which are hereby classified as:
      (1)   “Taxicab” as defined in this chapter; and
      (2)   “Chauffeured limousine” as defined in this chapter.
      (3)   Nothing herein shall apply to vehicles furnishing mass service for
more than 15 persons such as street railway cars, motor buses and omnibuses,
which move over fixed routes or on fixed schedules, or between fixed termini.
All such vehicles are subject to state law and must be driven by state-licensed
commercial drivers.
   (d)   “Street” means and includes any public street, alley or public way
within the corporate limits of the City.
   (e)   “Taxicab” means and includes any motor vehicle engaged in the business
of carrying passengers for hire or fare or offered for hire or fare to the
public for transportation, the rate of which is computed primarily by distance
traveled (metered) or a fixed rate (unmetered), and which follows no fixed or
prescribed route or schedule.
   (f)   “Public vehicle for hire company” means every corporation, company,
association, joint stock association, person, firm or copartnership, their
lessees, trustees, receivers or trustees appointed by any court whatsoever,
owning, controlling, operating or managing one or more public vehicle for hire
within the City.
   (g)   “Public vehicle for hire driver” means any person who drives or
operates a public vehicle for hire or fare and who is in actual control of a
public vehicle for hire on the streets of the City.
   (h)   “Public vehicle for hire operator” means and includes every
corporation, company, person, firm or copartnership, their lessees, trustees,
or receivers appointed by any court whatsoever, owning, controlling, operating,
maintaining, or managing one or more public vehicles for hire within the City.
      (Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.02 APPLICATION OF CHAPTER; EXEMPTIONS.
   (a)   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to public vehicles for
hire from other jurisdictions, and having no Sandusky City public vehicle for
hire business license, bringing passengers into the City. This chapter shall
apply to the solicitation or acceptance of passengers in the City, and no
operator or driver of any public vehicle for hire shall solicit or accept any
passengers within the City of Sandusky, hereinafter “the City”, for any
destination without first obtaining the necessary licenses required by this
chapter.
   (b)   The requirements of this chapter shall not apply to a commercial motor
vehicle as defined in Ohio R.C. 4506.01(D) and a bus as defined in Ohio R.C.
4501.01(I) operated by a person with a valid commercial driver’s license in
compliance with all applicable legal requirements contained in the Ohio Revised
Code.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.03  CHAPTER COMPLIANCE.
   No public vehicle for hire operator or public vehicle for hire company,
their lessees, trustees or receivers appointed by any court whatsoever, and no
public vehicle for hire driver shall operate any public vehicle for hire for
the transportation of persons for hire on any street within the corporate
limits of the City except in compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.04  PUBLIC VEHICLE FOR HIRE BUSINESS LICENSE.
   No public vehicle for hire company, operator or driver shall operate any
public vehicle for hire for the transportation of persons over any of the
streets of the City without first obtaining a public vehicle for hire business
license as provided in this chapter and such public vehicle for hire business
license is displayed in the public vehicle for hire.
   Public vehicle for hire operators and public vehicle for hire companies
operating without such a public vehicle for hire business license but which are
licensed by other municipalities may bring passengers into the City but shall
not solicit or accept any passengers within the City for any destination
without obtaining the necessary license required by this chapter.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.05  AUTHORITY OF THE CHIEF OF POLICE.
   Subject to the approval of the City Commission, the Chief of Police or
designee, is vested with the power and authority:
   (a)   To supervise and regulate the operation of all public vehicles for
hire within the City;
   (b)   To prescribe rules and regulations and to issue orders in conformity
with the provisions of this chapter applicable to any and all such public
vehicle for hire companies, operators and drivers.
      (Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.06 APPLICATION FOR PUBLIC VEHICLE FOR HIRE BUSINESS LICENSE.
   Each application for a public vehicle for hire business license shall be
filed with the Chief of Police on such forms as the Chief or designee shall
prescribe.
   Each application shall contain the following:
   (a)   The name and address of the applicant and if the applicant is other
than an individual, the nature of the organization whether incorporated, a
partnership, a limited liability company or otherwise;
   (b)   The name under which the applicant will conduct business;
   (c)   The nature and character of the business to be transacted;
   (d)   For each public vehicle for hire that is to be used, the type, make,
model, year and VIN number, owner and seating capacity;
   (e)   Proof of a policy of liability insurance for each public vehicle for
hire. Such policy shall be acceptable to and approved by the Chief of Police or
designee and shall be written by an insurance company authorized to carry on
business in the State of Ohio. The policy shall indemnify such public vehicle
for hire operator in the sum of at least one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000) for injury to one person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000)
for injury to more than one person, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000)
property damage in any one accident resulting from the operation of the public
vehicle for hire of such operator. The policy shall further contain a clause
obligating the insurer to give ten days written notice to the Chief of Police
or designee before cancellation or expiration of the policy. The public vehicle
for hire business license shall expire upon the lapse or termination of the
policy of insurance. Such policy of insurance shall also contain a provision
for the continuing liability thereunder for the full amount, notwithstanding
any recovery thereon. If at any time, in the judgment of the Chief of Police or
designee, such policy of insurance is not sufficient for any cause, the Chief
of Police or designee may require the operator of such public vehicle for hire
to replace the policy of insurance with another approved by the Police Chief or
designee;
   (f)   Proof that each public vehicle for hire has passed an annual
inspection conducted by the Ohio State Highway Patrol. This inspection shall be
arranged by the public vehicle for hire company or operator and obtained at
applicant’s expense. Each public vehicle for hire shall display a valid and
unexpired safety inspection sticker verifying inspection by the Ohio State
Highway Patrol.
   (g)   A certificate of registration with the City of Sandusky’s Income Tax
Department.
      (Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.07 ISSUANCE OF PUBLIC VEHICLE FOR HIRE BUSINESS LICENSE.
   (a)   If the Chief of Police or designee finds that the applicant is the
owner of each public vehicle for hire, and each public vehicle for hire is a
safe and fit conveyance and complies with all of the requirements of this
chapter, he/she shall issue a public vehicle for hire business license to the
applicant upon payment of the proper fee.
   (b)   If the Chief of Police or designee finds that the applicant does not
meet the requirements of this chapter, he/she shall notify the applicant and
state the reason(s) for denial.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.08 PUBLIC VEHICLE FOR HIRE BUSINESS LICENSE RENEWAL; TRANSFER.
   At the time of the issuance of the public vehicle for hire business license,
and annually thereafter on or before December 31, every public vehicle for hire
company and public vehicle for hire operator in the City shall pay to the Chief
of Police a fee as set forth by the City Manager and approved by the City
Commission. No public vehicle for hire business license shall be sold,
assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred.
(Ord. 22-085. Passed 5-9-22.)
   747.081 PUBLIC VEHICLE FOR HIRE BUSINESS LICENSE DECAL.
   The Chief of Police or designee shall furnish a decal for each public
vehicle for hire. The decal shall be affixed in the lower left-hand corner of
the rear window of each public vehicle for hire by the Chief of Police or
designee. The decal shall not be transferred from vehicle to vehicle. When the
public vehicle for hire is retired from service, the decal shall be removed and
destroyed by the Chief of Police or designee.
   Operation of a public vehicle for hire without the proper decal or failure
to have the decal destroyed pursuant to this section shall be cause for
revocation of the public vehicle for hire business license. It shall be
unlawful to display a public vehicle for hire business license decal on any
vehicle other than a public vehicle for hire that is owned by a validly
licensed public vehicle for hire business. (Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.082 EXTERIOR IDENTIFICATION REQUIRED.
   (a)   All public vehicles for hire shall have permanently printed or affixed
to the sides and rear of the vehicle the public vehicle for hire registered
business name and the word “taxicab” or “limousine” in a manner suitable to the
Chief of Police or designee. Such lettering shall be not less than three inches
in height.
   (b)   Public vehicle for hire operators that provide chauffeured limousine
services in the form of an executive sedan or a stretch limousine and that
provide proof of a policy of liability insurance for each public vehicle for
hire in the minimum amount of at least one million five hundred thousand
dollars ($1,500,000) combined single limit shall be exempt from providing
exterior identification as required by this section. Such policy shall be
acceptable to and approved by the Chief of Police or designee and shall be
written by an insurance company authorized to carry on business in the State of
Ohio. For purposes of this subsection:
      (1)   “Executive sedan” means a four-door sedan automobile having a
seating capacity of not more than three passengers behind the driver and a
minimum wheelbase of 114.5 inches. An executive sedan is equipped with standard
factory amenities, and the wheelbase shall not be altered.
      (2)   “Stretch limousine” means an automobile with a seating capacity of
not more than twelve passengers behind the driver, and a maximum wheelbase of
285 inches. The wheelbase has been factory or otherwise altered beyond the
original manufacturer’s specifications and meets standards of the United States
Department of Transportation. The automobile is equipped with amenities in the
rear seating area not normally found in passenger cars. These amenities may
include, but are not limited to, a television, musical sound system, telephone,
ice storage, power-operated dividers, or additional interior lighting.
      (3)   The terms “executive sedan” and “stretch limousine” excludes
trucks, funeral home vehicles, station wagons, vans, and minivans.
         (Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.09 REVOCATION OF PUBLIC VEHICLE FOR HIRE BUSINESS LICENSE.
   The Chief of Police or designee may revoke the public vehicle for hire
business license of any public vehicle for hire company or public vehicle for
hire operator for any false statement contained in the application provided in
Section
747.06 or the violation of any other provision of this chapter.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.10 APPEAL.
   Whenever the Chief of Police or designee has refused to issue or renew a
public vehicle for hire business license or shall have revoked such a license,
the applicant may appeal to the City Manager by filing with the City Manager a
written notice of appeal within ten business days after the date the decision
is mailed to or otherwise served upon the applicant.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.11 PUBLIC VEHICLE FOR HIRE DRIVER’S LICENSE; FEE.
   No person shall drive or operate a public vehicle for hire without first
having obtained a public vehicle for hire driver’s license from the Chief of
Police or designee. Each public vehicle for hire driver shall pay a license fee
as set forth by the City Manager and approved by the City Commission for each
year to the Chief of Police or designee. All public vehicle for hire driver’s
licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year.
(Ord. 22-085. Passed 5-9-22.)
   747.12  DRIVER’S LICENSE PHOTOGRAPH; LICENSE DISPLAY.
   The application for a driver’s license shall be made in writing by the
applicant upon blank forms to be furnished by the Chief of Police or designee.
The Chief of Police or designee shall photograph the applicant and reproduce
two copies. If the license is issued to the applicant, one photograph shall be
securely attached to the license issued to such person and the other shall be
filed with the application in the office of the Chief of Police. Each licensed
driver shall display at all times the license and photograph in his/her public
vehicle for hire so that any passenger occupying the public vehicle for hire
may inspect it. Upon demand of any police officer, the licensed driver shall
exhibit the license to him/her. When the application for a license is denied,
one copy of the photograph shall be kept in the files of the office of the
Chief of Police.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.13 REQUIREMENTS FOR PUBLIC VEHICLE FOR HIRE DRIVER’S LICENSE.
   No person shall be issued a public vehicle for hire driver’s license unless
such person:
   (a)   Is eighteen years of age or older;
   (b)   Possesses a valid operator’s license issued by the State of Ohio or
any other state;
   (c)   Has never been convicted of a felony involving the use, sale,
possession or transportation of illegal drugs within the seven years prior to
date of application;
   (d)   Has never been convicted of a misdemeanor involving the use, sale,
possession or transportation of illegal drugs or an offense under Ohio R.C.
4511.19(A)(1), (A)(2), (A)(3) or (A)(4) or a substantially similar municipal
OMVI ordinance or a substantially similar law or ordinance within any territory
of the United States, within the two years prior to the date of the
application.
   (e)   Fills out a blank form to be provided by the Chief of Police, giving
the applicant’s full name, current residence, previous residences for the five
years prior to the date of the application, age, race, height, eye and hair
color, place of birth, places of previous employment, and whether the applicant
has ever been convicted of a felony, and if so, the date of each conviction,
the name of the court in which convicted, and the case number of each
conviction. The applicant shall also request from the State of Ohio, on a form
to be provided by the Chief of Police, a Computer Criminal History (CCH). CCH’s
are required no more than twelve (12) months apart. The applicant understands
that failure to provide the CCH will result in the non-issuance of a public
vehicle for hire driver’s license. Any costs associated with the request shall
be paid by the applicant. The applicant shall also state whether he has
previously been licensed as a public vehicle for hire driver anywhere, and if
so, the current status of the license and whether the license was revoked and
for what cause.
   (f)   At the time the application is filed the applicant shall pay a fee of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) in addition to the cost of the C.C.H.
   The foregoing statement shall be signed and sworn to by the applicant and
filed as a permanent record in the office of the Chief of Police. Any false
statements or misrepresentations made by the applicant for the purpose of
securing a license shall forthwith, upon its discovery, work as a revocation of
the license.
(Ord. 15-160. Passed 11-23-15.)
   747.14 ISSUANCE OF PUBLIC VEHICLE FOR HIRE’S DRIVER’S LICENSE; RENEWALS.
   (a)   Upon satisfactory fulfillment of the foregoing requirements and a
consideration of the application and reports required in Section
747.13, the Chief of Police or designee shall approve or reject the
application.
   (b)   Upon approval of the application for a public vehicle for hire
driver’s license, the Chief of Police or designee shall issue a license to the
applicant which shall bear the name, address, a signature and photograph of the
applicant.
   (c)   Such public vehicle for hire driver’s license shall be in effect for
the remainder of the calendar year. All public vehicle for hire driver’s
licenses shall expire annually on December 31 unless sooner revoked.
   (d)   All applications for renewal of public vehicle for hire driver’s
licenses shall be filed with the Chief of Police or designee by December 1 of
each year and renewal licenses shall be issued in the same manner and upon the
same conditions as prescribed for initial public vehicle for hire driver’s
licenses.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.15 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF PUBLIC VEHICLE FOR HIRE DRIVER’S LICENSE.
   Any public vehicle for hire driver’s license may be suspended or revoked at
any time by the Chief of Police or designee for the violation of any of the
terms of this chapter or any other ordinance of the City, or any law of the
State of Ohio or of the United States. Any such suspension or revocation shall
be noted on the license, together with a statement of the reason therefor. No
driver whose license has been revoked shall again be licensed and nothing
contained herein shall be construed to require a public vehicle for hire
driver’s license fee to be refunded.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.16 NOTICE OF DENIAL, REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION AND HEARING REQUEST.
   If a license is denied, revoked or suspended, or a renewal is refused, the
Chief of Police or designee shall cause written notification of such denial,
revocation or suspension, or refusal to renew, to be given to the applicant by
certified mail at the address stated in the application, and such written
notification shall include the basis for such denial, revocation, suspension or
refusal. An applicant receiving such notification may request a hearing, in
writing, before the Chief of Police or designee. A hearing requested under this
section shall be held within seven business days of receiving the request.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.17 POSTING FARES; RECEIPTS.
   The rates of fare charged by the operator or driver of any taxicab shall be
posted in a conspicuous place in the taxicab, printed in a type not smaller
than one-half inch and no operator or driver of any taxicab shall charge a fare
or rate in excess of those so displayed. The owner, driver or person in charge
or control of a taxicab shall deliver to the person paying for the hire of such
taxicab, if demanded by such person at the time of payment of such fare, a
receipt therefor, which shall show the amount of fare paid, the point where
such person was accepted as a passenger and where discharged, the number of
passengers and the name of the company operating the taxicab.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.18 UNLAWFUL ACTS OF PUBLIC VEHICLE FOR HIRE OPERATORS OR DRIVERS.
   No operator or driver of a public vehicle for hire shall:
   (a)   Drive a public vehicle for hire while under the influence of alcohol
or any drug of abuse or ingest any alcohol or any drug of abuse whatsoever
while transporting passengers;
   (b)   Allow any public vehicle for hire to be used for immoral purposes;
   (c)   Fail, neglect or refuse to turn in to the Chief of Police, within
twenty-four hours, all the lost articles found in the public vehicle for hire;
   (d)   Drive or operate a public vehicle for hire upon any street of the
City, unless the owner thereof is operating pursuant to a public vehicle for
hire business license;
   (e)   Use any portion of the streets as a taxicab stand or permit a public
vehicle for hire in his charge to stand upon any portion of the streets, except
for such times as are necessary to load or unload passengers;
   (f)   Fail to notify the Chief of Police within twelve hours after an
accident, giving the time and location of the accident, the name of any person
injured, the condition of the injured, the character of the injury as far as
known and, in case of property damage, a description of the property and the
estimated amount of such damage;
   (g)   Travel up and down the City streets seeking customers, commonly called
“cruising”;
   (h)   Receive and discharge passengers at any place other than the curb in
any section of the City;
   (i)   Permit passengers to enter or leave, except at the side thereof
nearest the curb;
   (j)   Exceed the seating capacity of the car as shown by the application
filed with the Chief of Police.
      (Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.19 IMPOUNDING VEHICLES.
   Any public vehicle for hire being operated in violation of any provision of
this chapter may be impounded by the police. The vehicle shall remain impounded
until such time that the vehicle has been licensed as a public vehicle for hire
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter or an application to license the
vehicle as a public vehicle for hire pursuant to the provisions of this chapter
has been denied.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.20 PUBLIC SERVICE STREET REPAIR FUND.
   All moneys and receipts which are derived from the enforcement of this
chapter shall be credited and paid into a separate fund, which fund shall be
known as the Public Service Street Repair Fund. All moneys and receipts
credited to such Fund shall be used for the sole purpose of repairing streets,
avenues, alleys and lanes within the City.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
   747.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter is
guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense. For a second or subsequent
offense within one year, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth
degree.
(Ord. 08-024. Passed 4-14-08.)
CHAPTER 753
Transient Merchants
753.01    Definitions.
753.02    License required.
753.03    License application; fee.
753.04    License fees.
753.05    Issuance of license; conditions.
753.06    License revocation.
753.07    License limitations.
753.08    Exceptions.
753.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.64
      Licensing administration - see BUS. REG. Ch.
701
   753.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meaning ascribed to them unless the context clearly calls for a different
meaning:
(a)    "Goods" means any kind of merchandise, beverage, produce, food, or
commodity.
(b)    "Home sales" means a sale of personal property to the general public
conducted on or in any portion of the residence-property within a residential
zoning district, or property in nonconforming residential use in other zoning
districts, to include but not to be limited to garage sales, patio sales, yard
sales, carport sales, basement sales, porch sales, driveway sales and the like.
(c)    "Operate" means to conduct the business of the temporary store.
(d)    "Sale"means the transfer of ownership, with or without consideration, of
goods, or taking orders for the same, whether or not physical possession of the
goods is then given to the buyer or delivery is to be at a future time and/or
at a different place.
(e)    "Temporary store" means the whole or any part of a store, storeroom,
office, building, structure, improved or unimproved land, used for the sale of
goods where the seller of such goods operates such place for a period of less
than 120 days; and also includes a vehicle used for such purpose for any period
of time.
(f)    "Transient merchant"means a person who sells goods or offers them for
sale from a temporary store.
(g)    “Vehicle" means the same as set forth in Ohio R.C. 4501.01 (A).
      (Ord. 95-124. Passed 7-10-95.)
   753.02 LICENSE REQUIRED. 
   No transient merchant shall sell goods, or offer them for sale, from an
unlicensed temporary store. (Ord. 95-124. Passed 7-10-95.)
   753.03 LICENSE APPLICATION; FEE.
   (a)   Any person desiring to operate a temporary store shall make written
application to the City Manager on forms furnished by the City Manager. The fee
for an application to operate a temporary store shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00) and shall be nonrefundable. Not later than thirty days after the
filing of a completed application for a license, the applicant shall be
notified by the City Manager of the decision on the issuance or denial of the
license. Each application shall contain the following information:
(1)   The name and address of the owner of the goods to be sold.
(2)   A description of the place where such store is to be located and a site
plan indicating where merchandise will be displayed and signs are to be
located.
(3)   The nature and type of the goods to be offered for sale.
(4)   The day when the business of the temporary store will commence and the
day it will end.
(5)   The name and home and business address of the operator.
(6)   A copy of any appropriate licenses required by the County Health
Department pursuant to Ohio R.C. 3732.02 or may hereafter be amended.
(7)   Proof of authorization from the property owner of the property on which
the temporary store is to be located for the applicant to operate a temporary
store on said property.
(8)   Proof of registration with the City Division of Income Tax for income tax
collection purposes.
   (b)   Additional information may be required by the City Manager for the
review of such a license in order to provide and protect the public health,
safety, and welfare.
(Ord. 95-124. Passed 7-10-95.)
   753.04  LICENSE FEES.
    The fee for licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be fifty dollars
($50.00) for each month, or any part thereof, during which a temporary store is
to be operated. If the location of the temporary store is not owned by the
applicant or is leased for less than 120 days, it shall be prima facie evidence
that a license is required. (Ord. 95-124. Passed 7-10-95.)
   753.05  ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; CONDITIONS.
   When it appears to the City Manager that an application for a temporary
store has been properly made and the application fee paid, he shall issue a
license to the applicant, subject to the following conditions:
(a)    The period of licensing shall be not more than 120 days and the days
shall be consecutive.
(b)    Upon commencement of business and at all times during the operation of
the temporary store, the license shall be prominently displayed at the
temporary store.
(c)    That the location for the temporary store is properly zoned for such
operation and has the off-street parking spaces determined to be necessary for
the operation of said store according to the standards set by the Zoning Code,
or a minimum of three off-street parking spaces if not set by the Zoning Code.
(d)    That the temporary store is to be operated between the hours of 9:00
a.m. and 9:00 p.m. or sunset, whichever occurs first.
(e)    Compliance with all other pertinent ordinances of the City, State laws,
and health regulations.
   (Ord. 95-124. Passed 7-10-95.)
   753.06 LICENSE REVOCATION.
   The City Manager may revoke the license for violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 95-124. Passed 7-10-95.)
   753.07  LICENSE LIMITATIONS.
   A license may not be renewed, or the period of operation extended. No
license for a temporary store may be issued to the same owner and/or operator
for any location in the City within a period of eight months from the
expiration of a licensing period.
(Ord. 95-124. Passed 7-10-95.)
   753.08 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to judicial sales, sales by
executors or administrators, sales of unredeemed pledges by or on behalf of
licensed pawnbrokers, in the manner prescribed by law, sales of farm products,
farm implements, livestock, home sales, real estate, machinery and equipment,
automobiles accumulated by a bona fide dealer, vendors operating during
community events and festivals which are under the jurisdiction of the City's
festival committee, personal property not in the general line of merchandise
nor to any sale or auction held by any church, charitable organization or
fraternal organization provided such churches, charitable organizations or
fraternal organizations conduct their sale on real estate owned and/or occupied
by such organizations.
   The provisions of this chapter also shall not apply to sales by a person
operating a branch store provided that such person or the principal of such
person has engaged in and presently engages in the same kind of sales in
another location in the City and has done so for more than ninety days prior to
the opening of the branch store.
(Ord. 95-124. Passed 7-10-95.)
   753.99 PENALTY.
    Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two
hundred dollars ($200.00), or imprisoned not more than thirty days, or both.
Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 95-124. Passed 7-10-95.)

      Ohio R.C. 5589.10
STREETS, GRADES AND IMPROVEMENTS
   905.01 GRADES OF STREETS.
   The grade of any street shall refer to the elevation of the top or upper
surface of either of its curbs at any series of points thereon. The City
Engineer may establish the grade as provided in this chapter.
(1980 Code 97.01)
   905.02 CONDITIONS PRECEDENT TO IMPROVING STREETS.
   No department of the City shall accept, lay out, open, improve, grade, pave,
curb, or light any street or other way unless the street or way:
(a)   Shall have been accepted or opened or otherwise shall have received the
legal status of a public street or way prior to the effective date of this
section; or
(b)   Unless the street or way corresponds in location and extent with a street
or way shown on a recorded plat which shall have been legally accepted by the
City Commission.
      (1980 Code 97.02)
   905.03 OPENING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the City Engineer or his
authorized employees or agents, to make any opening in, to cut into, break, or
otherwise disturb any street, alley, or public way of the City unless a permit
therefor shall have been obtained prior to commencement of the work, as herein
provided.
(1980 Code 97.03)
SIDEWALKS AND CURBS, GRADES AND IMPROVEMENTS
   905.04  CONSTRUCTION; PERMITS.
   No person shall construct or repair any sidewalk or curb within the City,
without first obtaining a permit from the City Manager to do such work.
(1980 Code 97.05)
   905.05 APPLICATION.
   Every person, firm, or corporation desiring or required to construct or re-
lay a sidewalk or curb shall first make application in writing to the City
Manager to lay the sidewalk or curb, which application shall set forth the
location of the improvement, and the name and address of the owner of the
property abutting the proposed improvement.
(1980 Code 97.06)
   905.06  VERIFICATION OF GRADE AND LINE.
   The City Manager shall forthwith cause an investigation of the application
to be made; if the grade and line for the walk or curb have not already been
established, or if in the opinion of the City Manager the grade and line of the
walk or curb or either of them should be changed, then he shall establish the
grade and line for the walk or curb. The grades and lines shall be deemed
established and in force as soon as the City Manager shall have prepared a plan
therefor showing the location, width, elevation, and grades of the walk or curb
and the plan has been approved by the City Manager. The grade and line of any
curb or sidewalk heretofore laid shall not be changed without the written
permission or order of the City Manager.
(1980 Code 97.07)
   905.07 PERMIT FEES.
   Every applicant for a permit to re-lay or construct a sidewalk or curb shall
pay the Finance Director therefor the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for each
permit issued for the lot. The City Manager shall have authority to grant
permission to any property owner to repair his walk or curb. However, the grade
or line need not be changed. The repairs may be completed during daylight of
the day on which the work shall be started. Every property owner or agent who
shall make application for a permit to repair a sidewalk or curb the grade of
which need not be changed, shall pay the Finance Director the sum of five
dollars ($5.00) for the permit for each lot.
(1980 Code 97.08)
   905.08 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   Every person, firm, or corporation receiving a permit shall comply with the
provisions of all of the ordinances, rules, regulations, and specifications on
file in the office of the City Manager, grades and lines furnished by the City
Manager, and other instructions now in force and which may hereafter be
established regulating the construction, re-laying, and repairing of sidewalks
and curbs.
(1980 Code 97.09)
OBSTRUCTIONS AND HAZARDS TO STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
   905.09 BUILDING MATERIAL; PERMITS.
   Before any person, firm, or corporation shall be permitted to use any
portions of any street or other space belonging to the City, for the purpose of
depositing any building material or other property of any kind whatsoever
thereon, application for permission must be made to the City Manager of the
City, which permission shall be granted upon the payment of a fee of ten
dollars ($10.00). However, the granting of the permits shall be at the
discretion of the City Manager.
(1980 Code 97.15)
   905.10 UNLOADING ON STREET OR SIDEWALK.
   No person shall unload any heavy material in the streets of the City, by
throwing or letting the same fall upon the pavement of any street, alley,
sidewalk, or other public way, without first placing some sufficient protection
over the pavement.
(1980 Code 97.16)
   905.11 FENCE OR BUILDING.
   No person shall obstruct any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public way in
the City, by erecting thereon any fence or building, or permitting any fence or
building to remain thereon. Each day that any fence or building is permitted to
remain upon the public way, shall be deemed a separate offense.
(1980 Code 97.17)
   905.12 ENCUMBERING WITH BARRELS OR BOXES.
   No person shall encumber any street or sidewalk, or, being the owner,
occupant, or person having the care of any building or lot of land bordering on
any street or sidewalk, shall permit the same to be encumbered with barrels,
boxes, cans, articles, or substances of any kind, so as to interfere with the
free and unobstructed use thereof.
(1980 Code 97.18)
   905.13 REMOVAL OF ICE AND SNOW.
   (a)   The owner, occupant, or person having the care of any building or lot
of land bordering on any street with graded or paved sidewalks, within the
first 4 hours after daylight, following or during a fall of snow, shall cause
the snow to be removed from the walk. This provision shall include snow or ice
falling from any building.
   (b)   Whenever the sidewalk or any part thereof shall become encumbered with
ice, the owner, occupant, or person in control, within the first 4 hours after
daylight, following or during its formation, shall cause the sidewalk to be
made safe by removing the ice or sprinkling the same with sand or other
suitable substance.
(1980 Code 97.19)
   905.14 APPLICATION FOR PLANTING WITHIN STREET RIGHT OF WAY.
   A person may be permitted to place and maintain decorative plantings and
similar ornamentations on or in portions of the street right of way in front of
his property provided application is first made to the City Manager for
permission. Permission shall be granted by the City Manager when the safety and
convenience of the public is not and would not be infringed upon by the placing
and maintenance of the plantings and ornamentations and when the placing and
maintenance thereof is in accordance with uniform rules and regulations adopted
by the City Manager and approved by the City Commission. The permit shall be
for the calendar year, or the remaining portion thereof when the application is
made, and the fee for the permit shall be one dollar ($1.00).
(1980 Code 97.20)
   905.15 APPLICATION FOR PLANTINGS BY ORGANIZATIONS.
   In addition to the provisions of Section
905.14, an association or organization may also be permitted to place and
maintain decorative plantings and similar ornamentations on or in portions of
the street right of way providing the association or organization has the
written permission of the owner or lessee of the property for the planting or
ornamentation and the written permission is submitted with the application for
the permit. The permit fee in that case shall be one dollar ($1.00) for each
parcel of abutting property to which the permit applies.
(1980 Code 97.21)
   905.16  OBSTRUCTIONS IN STREETS, ALLEYS, OR PUBLIC PLACES PROHIBITED.
   Except under franchise or permit legally granted, no person shall place,
construct, erect, or maintain any pole, pipe, wire, main, conduit, sign, hole,
excavation, pavement, or any other object or structure, in, upon, along,
across, above, over, or under any street, alley, public way, public right of
way, public place, or public property; or in any other way obstruct, occupy, or
encroach upon the same.
(1980 Code 97.22)
   905.17 REMOVAL OF PREEXISTING OBSTRUCTIONS.
   Any person who has, prior to September 13, 1965, except under franchise or
permit legally granted, placed, constructed, or erected, and after that date
maintains, any pole, pipe, wire, main, conduit, sign, hole, excavation,
pavement, or any other object or structure, in, upon, along, across, above,
over, or under any street, alley, public way, public right of way, public
place, or public property shall remove the same upon order given by the City
Engineer. Failure or refusal to obey the order for a period of 7 days is a
violation of this section.
(1980 Code 97.23)
   905.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree. Each day's continued violation shall constitute a separate
offense.
                                                                                                  
CHAPTER 909
Building Numbering
909.01   House numbering plan.
909.02   Displaying numbers.
909.03   Change of numbers.
909.04   Removing numbers.
909.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.26
   909.01 HOUSE NUMBERING PLAN.
   Generally, and as nearly so as practicable, buildings shall be numbered in
the following uniform manner: buildings on streets running north and south
shall be numbered south from Sandusky Bay; on streets running east and west
they shall be numbered eastwardly and westwardly from Columbus Avenue. The
basis for all numbering shall assume that Columbus Avenue runs north and south
and numbers from 100 to 200 are assigned to that portion of Columbus Avenue
between Water and Market Streets. Even numbers shall be used for easterly and
southerly sides of streets and odd numbers for westerly and northerly sides. In
numbering, 100 numbers shall be allowed for each block of ordinary length and 3
numbers for each 66-foot frontage, except there shall be one number for each
10-foot frontage in business districts. The City Engineer shall have charge of
house numbering.
(1980 Code 97.60)
   909.02  DISPLAYING NUMBERS.
   Upon notification by the Engineer of the proper number of a building, the
owner of the building shall cause the number to be placed and continuously
maintained in a conspicuous place on the front of the building. If a building
stands back more than 45 feet from the street line, the number shall be
conspicuously displayed at or near the walk, driveway, or common entrance to
the building at the street line on a gate post, fence, tree, post, or other
appropriate place so as to be easily legible from the sidewalk.
(1980 Code 97.61)
   909.03  CHANGE OF NUMBERS.
   The Engineer shall be authorized to change the house numbering of any street
or part of a street or any individual building, when the change shall be
necessary by reason of readjustment of any kind such as inaccuracy or mistake,
or for any other cause.
(1980 Code 97.62)
   909.04 REMOVING NUMBERS.
   No person shall remove, alter or deface any house number, properly assigned
and placed on or near a building, or place or retain on any building any number
other than the one duly assigned by the Engineer.
(1980 Code 97.63)
   909.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree.
                                                                                                   
CHAPTER 913
Excavations
913.01   Excavation permit for each job.
913.02   Application for permit; fees.
913.03   Information in application; misrepresentations.
913.04   Inspection procedures.
913.05   Removal of rock.
913.06   Blasting.
913.07   License for blasting.
913.08   Obstructing traffic by excavations.
913.09   Material for backfill.
913.10   Lights and barricades.
913.11   Starting and completing work.
913.12   Work abandoned.
913.13   Illegal construction.
913.14   Permit and inspection fees.
913.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Excavation liability - see Ohio R.C. 723.49 et seq.
   913.01 EXCAVATION PERMIT FOR EACH JOB.
   Before any excavation is begun for any connection to any gas or water main,
or any other service, constructed in whole or in part in the City, a permit
shall be secured by the person by whom the connection is to be made.
(1980 Code 102.01)
   913.02 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FEES.
   Application for permits to excavate for or connect to any gas or water main,
or any other public service must be made in writing by the owner of the
property to be served or by his authorized agent for which permit a fee will be
charged. Inspection fees as hereinafter set forth shall also be paid at the
time permit is issued.
(1980 Code 102.02)
   913.03 INFORMATION IN APPLICATION; MISREPRESENTATIONS.
   All applications for permits shall give the precise location of the
property, number of the lot, the name of the street, the name of the owner, and
the name of the licensed excavator, sewer tapper, and sewer builder employed to
do the work and shall be filed with the City at least 24 hours previous to the
opening of the trench or commencing the work. No permits shall be deemed to
authorize anything not stated in the application, and for any misrepresentation
in the application, the permit of the licensed excavator, sewer tapper, or
sewer builder shall be suspended and if the misrepresentation appears to be
willful, his license may be revoked for a period of 6 months.
(1980 Code 102.03)
   913.04 INSPECTION PROCEDURES.
   Inspectors shall be notified by the persons doing the work when the same is
ready for inspection. All work, and the trench in which the same is laid, shall
be kept open, free and clear so that all the work is accessible at the time of
inspection. The City Engineer shall keep a record of the location of the tap,
type of construction (as to material and joints), or any unusual condition
encountered on all work inspected by him. (1980 Code 102.04)
   913.05 REMOVAL OF ROCK.
   If rock is found in any trench, it shall be removed to not less than 6
inches below the required grade of the pipe and the space filled with other
suitable material thoroughly tamped in place.
(1980 Code 102.05)
   913.06  BLASTING.
   No blast shall be fired within 5 feet of any public or private sewer, water
main, gas pipe, conduit, or any other underground service which may be in any
way injured by the blast. All blasting shall be covered with mats in such a
manner as to confine the rock to the trench in which the blast is located.
(1980 Code 102.06)
   913.07 LICENSE FOR BLASTING.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to permit a licensed excavator,
sewer tapper, and sewer builder to do blasting without first having secured a
blasting license therefor as provided for by the ordinances of the City.
   913.08  OBSTRUCTING TRAFFIC BY EXCAVATIONS.
   All material excavated from trenches shall be placed so as not to obstruct
traffic or cause unnecessary inconveniences to the public. Not more than 1/2 of
any public street shall be closed to traffic at any one time.
(1980 Code 102.08)
   913.09 MATERIAL FOR BACKFILL.
   Where it is necessary to remove any portion of a pavement, driveway, or
sidewalk for the excavation of any sewer, water main, gas pipe, or any other
service, the trench shall be backfilled with sand, gravel or fine crushed stone
thoroughly rammed or settled in place in such a manner as to prevent further
settlement within the limits of the pavement, driveway, or sidewalk, and for a
distance of 5 feet beyond the limits of the same.
(1980 Code 102.09)
   913.10 LIGHTS AND BARRICADES.
   The person doing any excavating in any street, alley, or public grounds in
the City shall place and maintain on the banks of the trench proper barricades
and lights to guarantee the public against accidents during the progress of the
work in accordance with standards of the Department of Engineering.
(1980 Code 102.11)
   913.11 STARTING AND COMPLETING WORK.
   All work shall be started within 5 days after a permit for the same has been
secured and when started shall be carried to completion without delay unless
prevented by conditions over which the person doing the work has no control.
(1980 Code 102.12)
   913.12  WORK ABANDONED.
   Should the work or any trench in which the same is located be abandoned or
unnecessarily delayed by the person doing the work, the City may, at the
expense of that person or his bondsman, fill or cause to be filled the open
trench and the street, alley, or public grounds restored to their original
condition.
(1980 Code 102.13)
   913.13  ILLEGAL CONSTRUCTION.
   Any person, firm, or corporation who or which shall make an illegal
connection to a sewer, water main, gas main, or to any other public service
shall remove that connection when ordered by the City Engineer. On failure to
comply with the order within 10 days, it shall be the duty of the City Engineer
to cause the connection to be removed and the expense thereby incurred shall be
paid by the offending person, firm, or corporation and in default of the
payment for a period of 10 days the expense shall be certified to the County
Auditor to be assessed against the property for which the connection was made.
(1980 Code 102.14)
   913.14  PERMIT AND INSPECTION FEES.
   (a)   For each excavation permit issued by the City Engineer, a fee of five
dollars ($5.00) will be charged together with an inspection fee of eighty
dollars ($80.00). These fees shall accompany the application for a permit.
   (b)   The inspection fee shall be for 2 inspections of the work done. Any
additional inspections, necessary in the opinion of the City Engineer, shall be
paid for by the owner at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) each.
(1980 Code 102.15)
   913.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned more than 90 days, or
both. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense.
(1980 Code 102.99)
                                                                                                  
CHAPTER 917
Trees
917.01   Purpose.
917.02   Definitions.
917.03   Authority of Superintendent of Forestry.
917.04   Arborist's license and bond.
917.05   Damage to trees.
917.06   Fastening materials to trees and shrubs.
917.07   Planting, trimming or removing trees.
917.08   Public utilities.
917.09   Tree protection during construction.
917.10   Moving of trees.
917.11   Trimming trees.
917.12   Tree topping.
917.13   Interference with the Superintendent.
917.14   Public nuisance.
917.15   Abatement of nuisance.
917.16   Appeal from order of Superintendent or Housing Code Compliance
Officer.
917.17   Authority of Superintendent or Housing Code Compliance Officer to
enter private premises.
917.18   Trees in subdivisions.
917.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Tree Commission - see ADM. Ch.
183
   Power to regulate shade trees and shrubbery - see Ohio R.C. 715.20
   Assessments for tree planting or maintenance - see Ohio R.C. 727.011
   917.01  PURPOSE.
   It is the policy of the City to regulate and control planting, removal,
maintenance and protection of trees in the City; to eliminate and guard against
dangerous conditions which may result in injury to persons using the public
areas of the City; to promote and enhance the beauty of the City; to protect
trees located in public areas from undesirable and unsafe planting, removal,
maintenance and protection practices; and to guard all trees within the City
against the spread of disease or pests.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.02  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "City" means the City of Sandusky, Ohio.
   (b)   "Superintendent" means the Superintendent of Forestry of the City or
his or her designee.
   (c)   "Tree lawn" means the parcel or area of land located between the curb
and a sidewalk or the City right of way where no sidewalk exists.
   (d)   "Public way" means any public street, road, boulevard, alley or
sidewalk.
   (e)   "Public area" means any public way, park, or other land owned, leased,
or controlled by the City.
   (f)   “Maintenance" and "protection" include all operations of trimming,
pruning, spraying, injecting, fertilizing, treating, bracing, doing survey work
and cutting above or below the ground.
   (g)   "Street tree" or "tree" means a tree or shrub in a public place,
public area, or public way, except where otherwise indicated.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.03 AUTHORITY OF SUPERINTENDENT OF FORESTRY.
   (a)   The Superintendent shall have jurisdiction and supervision over all
trees planted or growing in public places. No person shall plant any tree in a
public place without permission of the Superintendent.
   (b)   The Superintendent shall have the authority and it shall be his or her
duty to plant, to remove, to maintain, and to protect trees on all public areas
as may be necessary to ensure safety or to preserve the symmetry and beauty of
such grounds.
   (c)   The Superintendent or Housing Code Compliance Officer shall have the
authority and it shall be his or her duty to order the trimming, preservation,
or removal of trees upon private property when he or she finds such action
necessary to public safety or to prevent the spread of disease or insects to
public trees or places;
   (d)    The Superintendent or Housing Code Compliance Officer shall have the
authority, and it shall be his or her duty to supervise all work done under a
permit issued in accordance with the provisions of this chapter; and
   (e)   The Superintendent or Housing Code Compliance Officer shall have the
authority to affix reasonable conditions to the granting of any permit under
this chapter.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.04  ARBORIST'S LICENSE AND BOND.
   No person or firm shall engage in the business or occupation of pruning,
treating or removing trees within the City without first applying for and
procuring a license. The license fee shall be set by the City and shall be paid
annually in advance. No license shall be required of any public service
endeavors. Before any license is issued, each applicant shall first file
evidence of possession of Workers' Compensation and of liability insurance as
required by the City.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.05  DAMAGE TO TREES.
   No person shall in any public area of the City break, injure, mutilate, kill
or destroy any tree or shrub; permit any animal under his control to do so;
permit any fire to injure any portion of any tree or shrub; permit any toxic
chemical to seep, drain or be emptied on or about any tree.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.06 FASTENING MATERIALS TO TREES AND SHRUBS.
   No person shall fasten any sign, rope, wire or other material(s) to, around
or through any public trees without obtaining a written permit from the
Superintendent, except in emergencies such as storms or accidents.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.07 PLANTING, TRIMMING OR REMOVING TREES.
   No person shall on any public area including tree lawns, plant, trim or
remove a tree without obtaining a written permit from the Superintendent.
Should the Superintendent deny the issuance of a permit, an appeal may be filed
with the City Tree Commission which may affirm or reverse the decision of the
Superintendent.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.08 PUBLIC UTILITIES.
   Public utility work affecting trees shall be limited to the actual
necessities of the services of the company and such work shall be done in a
neat and professional manner and according to accepted specifications and
standards. Any public utility the work of which affects trees shall be liable
to reimburse the City for the cost of any removals and of new tree plantings to
replace affected trees.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.09 TREE PROTECTION DURING CONSTRUCTION.
   No person in charge of or responsible for the erection, alteration or
removal of any building or structure in the City shall permit a public tree in
the vicinity of such operation to stand without a good and sufficient guard or
protection to prevent possible injury. The quality of the guard or protection
shall be determined by the Superintendent or Housing Code Compliance Officer.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.10 MOVING OF TREES.
   All moving of trees upon any public place in the City made necessary by the
moving of a building or structure or any other private enterprise shall be done
under the supervision and with the written permission of the Superintendent and
at the expense of the applicant or person seeking the removal of such tree.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.11 TRIMMING TREES.
   The Superintendent shall keep all trees standing upon any public area in the
City trimmed so that the branches of the same projecting over any public street
beyond the curb line do not conflict with the public welfare to such an extent
that the lowest branches of such trees do not come within nine feet of the
ground where they overhang any public sidewalk or public area or within
thirteen feet of the ground where they overhang a public highway. All trees
standing upon private property within the City and having branches projecting
into public highways or public places shall, under the supervision of the
Superintendent, be kept trimmed by the owner or occupant of such private
property to the same standard as specified in this section for trees in public
areas.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.12  TREE TOPPING.
   As a normal practice, no person, firm or City department shall top any
street or park tree or other tree in public areas. "Topping" means the severe
cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the
tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure
the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees
under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are
impractical may be exempted from this section at the determination of the
Superintendent.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.13 INTERFERENCE WITH THE SUPERINTENDENT.
   No person shall interfere with the Superintendent or his subordinates or
assistants or Housing Code Compliance Officers while engaged in or about the
carrying out of the provisions of this chapter or the doing of any of the work
ordered by the City Commission, City Manager or Director of Public Services.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.14  PUBLIC NUISANCE
   The Superintendent or Housing Code Compliance Officer shall have the right
to declare any tree or shrub growing upon private property which is:
   (a)    Interfering with the use of any public area,
   (b)    Infected with an infectious plant disease, or
   (c)    Endangering the life, health or safety of persons or property, as a
public nuisance.
      (Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.15 ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE.
   If the Superintendent or Housing Code Compliance Officer determines, with
reasonable certainty upon inspection or examination, that any nuisance tree or
shrub, as herein defined, exists in or upon any private premises, he or she
shall notify, in writing, the owner or tenant having charge of such premises.
Within thirty days after the issuance of such notice, the person shall cause
the treatment, trimming, or removal and destruction of the nuisance tree as
directed in the written notice. No damages shall be awarded the owner or tenant
having charge of such premises. Should the owner or tenant refuse or neglect to
comply with the terms of the written notice within thirty days after receiving
it, the Superintendent or Housing Code Compliance Officer shall cause the
removal, treatment or trimming of the nuisance tree. The expense thereof shall
be assessed as a lien against the property for collection as other taxes.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.16 APPEAL FROM ORDER OF SUPERINTENDENT OR HOUSING CODE COMPLIANCE
OFFICER.
   A person who receives an order from the Superintendent or Housing Code
Compliance Officer and objects to all or a part thereof, may, within fourteen
days of receipt thereof, notify the Superintendent or Housing Code Compliance
Officer in writing of his desire to appeal the order. The appeal is presented
to the Sandusky City Tree Commission which, by a majority vote, may affirm,
reverse or modify the order.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.17 AUTHORITY OF SUPERINTENDENT OR HOUSING CODE COMPLIANCE OFFICER TO
ENTER PRIVATE PREMISES.
   The Superintendent or his representatives or Housing Code Compliance
Officer, after giving advance notice to the owner or agent having charge, shall
have the authority to enter upon private premises at reasonable times for the
purpose of examining and inspecting any suspected nuisance tree. All nuisance
trees so designated under the provision of Section
917.14 may be appropriately marked by the Superintendent or Housing Code
Compliance Officer.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.18  TREES IN SUBDIVISIONS.
   (a)     Street trees shall be planted in all subdivisions within the City,
including land abutting any street previously opened as well as those opened
for the subdivision. Installation shall be made under the supervision of the
Superintendent.
   (b)    The number, size, species and locations of the street trees planted
in subdivisions shall be in accordance with a tree plan mutually agreed upon by
the Sandusky City Tree Commission, and the developer.
   (c)    A zoning permit shall not be issued to any subdivision until and
unless a street tree plan has been approved, and an escrow account established
or a surety bond deposited in an amount equal to the cost of the trees and the
planting of the same as shall be determined by the City Director of Public
Services to ensure compliance with this chapter and the regulations adapted
hereunder.
   (d)    In the alternative, the developer of a subdivision may request the
City Manager to let the work required to satisfy the street tree plan on public
bid. In the event the accepted bid exceeds the escrowed account or surety bond,
the developer shall increase the same, or reimburse the amount of the
difference.
   (e)    The developer of a subdivision shall complete the street tree plan
within two years from the date of the issuance of the zoning permit. Failure to
do so shall be construed to be a default and the escrow account or surety bond
shall be forfeited. Funds derived as a result of any such forfeiture shall be
expended by the Superintendent to implement the street tree plan for the
project for which it was originally intended. (Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
   917.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not to exceed
one hundred dollars ($100.00). In addition, the person shall replace the tree
with a size and species recommended by the Sandusky City Tree Commission. Each
tree affected by noncompliance with this chapter shall constitute a separate
violation.
(Ord. 15-143. Passed 10-26-15.)
CHAPTER 919
Rights-of-Way Ordinance
919.01   Short title.
919.02   Definitions.
919.03   Purpose.
919.04   Construction and repair of facilities.
919.05   Obstruction of rights-of-way.
919.06   Application for rights-of-way construction permits.
919.07   Issuance of rights-of-way construction permits.
919.08   Rights-of-way construction permit fees.
919.09   Location of facilities.
919.10   Restoration of rights-of-way.
919.11   Relocation of facilities.
919.12   Temporary movement of facilities.
919.13   Tree trimming.
919.14   Joint planning and cooperation.
919.15   Erection and common use of poles and ducts.
919.16   Safety requirements.
919.17   Maps.
919.18   Indemnification.
919.19   No recourse.
919.20   Liability insurance and bonds.
919.21   Written notice.
919.22   Severability.
919.23   Effective date.
919.24   Removal of facilities.
919.25   Revocation.
919.26   Reservation of rights.
919.27   Non-enforcement and waivers by City.
919.28   Captions.
919.29   Application to City.
919.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Improvements - see CHTR. Sec.
35 et seq.
   Assessments - see Ohio R.C. 701.05, Ch. 727
   Power to establish and care for streets - see
      Ohio R.C. 715.19, 717.01, 723,01
   Openings by the Municipality - see Ohio R.C. 723.02
   Dedication and acceptance - see Ohio R.C. 723.03
   Change of name, vacating and narrowing streets - see
      Ohio R.C. 723.04 et seq.
   Sprinkling - see Ohio R.C. 723.16 et seq.
   Surface treatment - see Ohio R.C. 723.23, 723.31
   Excavation liability - see Ohio R.C. 723.49 et seq.
   Changing established grade - see Ohio R.C. 727.07
   Digging, excavating and piling earth on streets - see
      Ohio R.C. 5589.10
   919.01  SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Rights-of-way
Ordinance."
(Ord. 00-261. Passed 9-25-00.)
   919.02  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and
their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in
the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number
include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely
directory.
(a)    "Cable operator" has the same meaning as in section 2 of the "Cable
Communications Policy Act of 1984," 96 Stat. 2779, 47 U.S.C.A. 522, as amended.
(b)    "City" means the entire City of Sandusky, Ohio as the same now or in the
future may exist.
(c)    "Commission" means the City Commission of Sandusky, Ohio.
(d)    "Facilities" means the utility poles, wires, cables, lines, guys,
anchors, manholes, vaults, pipes, conduits, ducts, pedestals, antenna,
transformers, crossbars, repeaters, hubs, routers, and other equipment and
related appurtenances owned, controlled or used by cable operators and utility
service providers.
(e)    “Force majeure” means a strike, acts of God, acts of public enemies,
riots, epidemics, landslides, lightening, earthquakes, fires, tornadoes,
storms, floods, washouts, droughts, civil disturbances, explosions, partial or
entire failure of utilities, orders of any kind of a government of the United
States of America or of the State of Ohio or any of their departments,
agencies, political subdivisions, or any other cause or event not reasonably
within the control of the disabled party.
(f)    "Grantee" means a person to whom a rights-of-way construction permit is
granted, and its agents, employees and contractors.
(g)    “Person” means an individual, firm, corporation, limited liability
company, partnership, proprietorship, association, or legal entity or
organization of any kind.
(h)    "Rights-of-way" means the surface, the air space above the surface, and
the area below the surface, including the entire width, of any public streets,
highway, roadways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts, places, curbs, sidewalks,
rights-of-way, or other public ways in the City which have been or may
hereafter be dedicated to or otherwise acquired by the City.
(i)    "Rights-of-way construction permit" means a permit issued pursuant to
this chapter which authorizes the grantee the right to construct or place
facilities in the rights- of-way subject to and in accordance with this
chapter.
(j)    "Utility service provider" means a natural gas company, local exchange
telephone company, interexchange telecommunications company, electric company,
or any other person that occupies a public way to deliver natural gas, electric
or telecommunications services.
      (Ord. 00-261. Passed 9-25-00.)
   919.03 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to manage and administer the impacts of
utility service providers, cable operator and other person's use of the rights-
of-way.
(Ord. 00-261. Passed 9-25-00.)
   919.04 CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR OF FACILITIES.
    (a)    No utility service provider, cable operator, or person shall
construct, install, or place facilities in the rights-of-way without prior
consent of the City, which consent shall be set forth in a rights-of-way
construction permit issued by the City as provided in Section
919.07 of this chapter.
   (b)    A utility service provider, cable operator, or person seeking to
repair, maintain, construct, install, or place facilities in the rights-of-way
in a manner that requires cutting, breaking, opening, boring under, or altering
street pavement, or digging, excavating, or performing any other work or
activity which disturbs the existing surface or subsurface structure,
composition, or soil compaction of the rights-of-way shall obtain, in addition
to any permit required under paragraph (a) of this section, a street opening
permit under Section
905.03 of the Codified Ordinances of the City.
(Ord. 00-261. Passed 9-25-00.)
   919.05 OBSTRUCTION OF RIGHTS-OF-WAY.
   No utility service provider, cable operator, or person shall obstruct or
place obstructing materials in the rights-of-way without prior consent of the
City, which consent shall be set forth in a permit issued by the Director of
Engineering Services under Section
905.16 of the Codified Ordinances of the City; provided however, utility
service providers and cable operators may place temporarily trucks, cones,
pumps, ventilating equipment, trailers, guards, and other facilities in the
rights-of-way in order to enter existing manholes and other underground
structures to perform routine repair and maintenance of their facilities which
repairs and maintenance do not require cutting, breaking, opening, boring
under, or altering street pavement, or digging, excavating, or performing any
other work or activity which disturbs or alters the existing surface,
subsurface, structure, composition, or soil compaction of the rights-of-way. In
no event shall the rights-of-way be obstructed for more than twelve (12) hours
in any twenty-four (24) hour period without prior consent of the City set forth
in a permit issued by the Director of Engineering Services under Section
905.16 and in no event shall traffic be obstructed on more than one half of any
public street at any one time. (Ord. 00-261. Passed 9-25-00.)
   919.06 APPLICATION FOR RIGHTS-OF-WAY CONSTRUCTION PERMITS.
   (a)    Any utility service provider, cable operator or person seeking to
obtain a rights-of- way construction permit shall file an application with the
Director of Engineering Services. The application shall be in such form as the
Director of Engineering Services directs, but at a minimum shall be signed by
such utility service provider, cable operator or person, or a duly authorized
agent thereof; shall incorporate, directly or by reference, the terms of this
chapter; shall set forth the applicant's consent to and agreement to comply
with the terms of the application, chapter, and the rights-of-way permit; and
shall require the applicant to provide the following information:
(1)   The name, address and telephone number of both applicant and its agent
upon whom service can be made and notices provided;
(2)   A statement as to the nature of the applicant's business, whether its
operations and facilities are subject to regulation by the Public Utilities
Commission of Ohio or federal regulatory agency, and whether it is certified or
authorized by the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio to provide service in
Ohio;
(3)   Location of the proposed construction;
(4)   Type of facility to be installed or constructed;
(5)   Method of construction, installation, or placement to be used;
(6)   Estimated time to complete construction;
(7)   Whether street pavement will be cut, broken, opened, or bored under;
(8)   Whether traffic will be obstructed and, if so the portion of the rights-
of-way obstructed and the dates of the obstruction;
(9)   Proposed means of restoring the rights-of-way;
(10)   A statement describing how traffic flow will be maintained during the
construction period; and
(11)   A description of the purpose and use of the facilities constructed,
installed, or placed in the rights-of-way (power with voltage, gas with maximum
allowable operating pressure, etc.) and other pertinent details.
   (b)    If the applicant is not certified or authorized by the Public
Utilities Commission of Ohio to provide service in Ohio, applicant shall also
submit such additional information as the Director of Engineering Services
requests to determine the financial, technical and managerial expertise of the
applicant to construct, operate and maintain facilities in the right-of-way.
   (c)    Applicants shall also submit, as an attachment to their application,
scale drawings showing completely the nature, location, construction materials
and design of the facilities to be installed or constructed. Such drawings
shall include:
(1)   Street and/or road names;
(2)   A north arrow;
(3)   The offset, in feet and inches, from the centerline of the roadway to the
proposed facilities to be constructed or installed;
(4)   The rights-of-way limits;
(5)   The pavement width;
