   1349.01  ADOPTION OF ELECTRICAL CODE.
   The Electrical Code set forth in the following sections is established and
adopted for the City.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.02  EXAMINING BOARD.
   The provisions of this Code establishing an Electrician Examining Board and
regulating its functions are set forth in Chapter
1313.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.03 ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR; WORK ON OWN PREMISES BY NONELECTRICIAN.
   For the purpose of this chapter, an electrical contractor shall be any
individual, partnership or corporation, other than a public utility company as
stated in Section
1349.10 hereof, or a plant as stated in Section
1349.09, hereof, that proceeds with or employs others for, the construction,
alteration, repairs or additions to any electrical wiring for the purpose of
furnishing heat, light or power within the limits of the City. The provisions
of this chapter shall not be construed to prevent an individual who is the
owner and occupant of the one, two or three-family dwelling or its accessory
structure and who observes the provisions of this chapter and other ordinances
of the City relating to electrical wiring, upon procuring a permit therefor,
from installing, altering or repairing, by and for himself, the electrical
wiring on his property or premises.
(Ord. 01-216. Passed 9-24-01.)
   1349.04 CLASSES OF LICENSES.
   Three classes of licenses and certificates shall be issued by the City
Manager which shall be designated respectively as Journeyman Electrician’s
License, Residential Electrician’s License and Apprentice Electrician’s
License.
   Electrical Contractors shall be certified by the State of Ohio and shall
obtain a license issued by the Ohio Construction Industry Examination Board
pursuant to Chapter 4740 of the Ohio Revised Code. (Ord. 12-098. Passed 9-24-
12.)
   1349.05 ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR'S LICENSES, CLASS A.
   (Former Section 1349.05 was repealed by Ordinance 01-216, passed September
24, 2001.)
   1349.06 JOURNEYMAN ELECTRICIAN'S LICENSE, CLASS B.
   (a)   No person shall install, alter or repair, within the City limits, any
electrical wiring, devices or equipment for which a permit is required by this
chapter, unless the individual possesses a current journeyman electrician’s
license and only while employed by an electrical contractor possessing a
current State of Ohio Electrical Contractor’s license. Application for a
journeyman electrician’s license shall be made in writing to the Examining
Board of Electrician’s stating the name, experience and qualifications of the
applicant. Upon the applicant passing an examination with a grade of seventy
percent (70%) or more, a license shall be granted to the individual applying
for the same and this license shall grant to the individual the right to
execute the work of installing, altering or repairing within the City limits
any electrical wiring, devices or equipment. Journeyman electricians shall only
be permitted to perform electrical work under the supervision of an Electrical
Contractor that is certified by the State of Ohio and possesses a current
license issued by the Ohio Construction Industry Examination Board.
   A journeyman electrician shall not be permitted to lend their license to
another individual, nor procure permits in their name or any other individual's
name for electrical installations.
   (b)   A journeyman electrician license shall be granted only to persons who:
      (1)   Have had at least four years' experience as an apprentice
electrician or the equivalent thereof in training or education.
      (2)   Participate and pass the above-mentioned examination.
   (c)   Individuals who possess the journeyman electrician’s license shall be
permitted to perform electrical installations/alterations in all phases of the
electrical construction industry including, but not limited to: residential,
commercial, industrial and institutional applications.
(Ord. 12-098. Passed 9-24-12.)
   1349.06.1 RESIDENTIAL ELECTRICIAN’S LICENSE, CLASS C.
   (a)   No person shall install, alter or repair, within the City limits any
electrical wiring, devices or equipment in a residence for which a permit is
required by this chapter, unless the individual possesses a current residential
electrician’s license and only while employed by an electrical contractor
possessing a current State of Ohio Electrical Contractor’s license. Application
for a residential electrician’s license shall be made in writing to the
Examining Board of Electricians, stating the name, experience and
qualifications of the applicant. Upon the applicant passing an examination with
a grade of seventy percent (70%) or more, a license shall be granted to the
individual applying for the same and this license shall grant to the individual
the right to execute the work of installing, altering or repairing within the
City limits any electrical wiring, devices or equipment within one, two and
three family dwelling applications. Residential electricians shall not be
issued permits to perform electrical work as required in Section
1349.13.
   (b)   A residential electrician shall be permitted to perform electrical
installations in new residential applications only if under the supervision of
a currently licensed journeyman electrician or current electrical contractor.
   (c)   A residential electrician shall not be permitted to lend their license
to another individual, nor procure permits in their name or any other
individual’s name for electrical installations.
   (d)   A residential electrician license shall be granted only to persons
who:
      (1)   Have had at least four years’ experience as an apprentice
electrician or the equivalent thereof in training or education.
      (2)   Participate and pass the above-mentioned examination.
   (e)   Individuals who possess the residential electrician’s license shall be
permitted to perform electrical installations/alterations in 1, 2 and 3 family
residential applications as prescribed in the Residential Code of Ohio for one,
two and three family dwellings.
(Ord. 12-098. Passed 9-24-12.)
   1349.07  APPRENTICE ELECTRICIAN'S LICENSE.
   (a)   An apprentice electrician's license shall authorize the applicant to
engage in or work at the electrical trade or occupation within the City as an
assistant to and under the direct supervision of a licensed journeyman
electrician. A reasonable ratio of apprentice to journeyman/contractor shall be
maintained to assure that the apprentice is being properly trained in the
electrical trade.
   An apprentice electrician shall not be permitted to lend his license to
another individual, nor procure permits in his name or any other individual's
name for electrical installations.
   (b)   An apprentice electrician's license shall be granted only to persons
who, for not more than five years:
(1)   Are undergoing an apprenticeship or course of training for the purpose of
learning the trade or occupation of an electrician;
(2)   Register with the Board of Examiners on forms supplied and state their
name and address, together with the name and address of their employer and give
notice to the Administrative Authority within five days of any change of
address or employer;
(3)   Have been issued a card by the Administrative Authority with "Apprentice"
plainly set forth in imposing type, with their name, the name of their
employer, the date of issue and the number of years worked as an apprentice;
(4)   Pay a registration fee for each calendar year or part of a calendar year
in an amount established by the Director of Engineering Services and approved
by the City Commission. A schedule of fees shall be kept on file in the office
of the Department of Engineering Services.
         (Ord. 01-216. Passed 9-24-01.)
   1349.08 LICENSE FEES AND PERMITS.
   (a)   The examination fee for the journeyman electrician’s license and the
residential electrician’s license shall be established by the Director of
Engineering Services, approved by City Commission and shall not be refundable.
Upon passing the examination successful candidates may make application for a
journeyman electrician’s license or residential electrician’s license. The cost
for the license and annual renewal thereof, shall be established by the
Director of Engineering Services, approved by City Commission, and shall not be
refundable. A schedule of fees shall be kept on file in the office of the
Department of Engineering Services.
   (b)   The licensing period shall be for the calendar year or part thereof.
Applications for the renewal of each license shall be made at least ten days
before the expirations date of the old license, and upon approval of the
Examining Board, the license shall be renewed for a period of one year. Should
the licensee fail to apply for renewal within a thirty-day period after the
date of the expiration, the license shall become null and void.
   (c)   Except as provided in subsection (d) hereof, no permit shall be issued
to any person to do or cause to be done any electrical installations regulated
by this Electrical Code, except to a person holding a valid and unexpired
electrical contractor’s license issued by the Ohio Construction Industry
Examination Board pursuant to Chapter 4740 of the Ohio Revised Code and is
currently registered with the City as required by Section
 1317.03 of the City Code.
   (d)   Any permit required by this Code may be issued to any person to do any
work regulated by this Code in a one, two and three-family dwelling used
exclusively for living purposes, including the usual accessory buildings and
quarters in connection with such buildings, provided the person is the bona
fide owner of such dwelling and that same will be occupied by said owner and
that said owner shall personally purchase all material and perform all labor in
connection therewith, and complying with the requirements of this Code.
(Ord. 12-098. Passed 7-24-12.)
   1349.09  PLANT DEFINED; NO PERMITS REQUIRED.
   (a)   For the purposes of this chapter, a "plant" means a manufacturing or
industrial concern which maintains in the City its own electricians to install,
alter or repair electrical wiring, devices or equipment. Such entities shall
not be required to obtain permits, as issued under this chapter, or to pay
inspection fees for electrical work performed within their own building or
premises if such work is in the nature of general maintenance of the existing
electrical system. The installations, alterations or repairs permitted herein
are to be made in accordance with the National Electrical Code, its supplements
and revisions. Electrical contractors performing electrical installations,
including those installations which are in the nature of general maintenance,
within plants are required to comply with the other provisions of this Code and
are subject to inspection, permit and licensing requirements.
   (b)   Electrical service installations which require new or additional
service-entrance conductors, service equipment or meters shall be installed by
a properly licensed electrical contractor who employs properly licensed
journeymen and apprentice electricians. The electrical contractor shall also
secure proper permits and pay the appropriate permit and inspection fees for
the related installation. The service installations are subject to inspection
by the Electrical Inspector for authorization to energize the service by the
electric utility.
   (c)   Electrical wiring, devices and equipment within or on new buildings,
structures or additions to existing plant buildings shall be installed by a
properly licensed electrical contractor who employs properly licensed
journeymen and apprentice electricians. The electrical contractor shall also
secure proper permits and pay the appropriate permit and inspection fees for
the related installation. The new wiring installations are subject to
inspection and approval by the Electrical Inspector.
(Ord. 92-025. Passed 2-24-92.)
   1349.10 PUBLIC UTILITY; NO PERMITS REQUIRED.
   Public utility companies and corporations engaged in the manufacture or
distribution of electrical energy for commercial purposes shall not be required
to obtain permits as issued under this chapter, or to pay inspection fees for
the manufacture, transmission, distribution and metering of electrical energy
and the installation, maintenance, repairs and replacement of the necessary and
incidental equipment thereof by them. The point of termination of the overhead
secondary service conductors shall be the limit of exemption to the local
electric utility, except as to the meeting only thereof. Telephone, telegraph
and district messenger companies shall not be required to obtain permits as
issued under this chapter, or to pay inspection fees for the operation of
signals, control circuits or the transmission of intelligence.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.11 ELECTRICIANS IN PLANTS AND PUBLIC UTILITIES; NO LICENSES REQUIRED.
   Electricians employed by plants and public utilities, while employed for the
specific work as outlined in Sections
1349.09 and
1349.10 hereof, are not required to be licensed under the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.12 ELEVATOR AND ESCALATOR WORK; NO PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No permit or license shall be required for the installation or maintenance
of wiring, electrical devices or equipment in connection with elevators, either
passenger or freight, dumbwaiters, escalators or their accessories, when the
installations are made in accordance with Bulletin 110 of the Industrial
Commission of the State, covering specific requirements for the construction,
inspection,, maintenance and operation of elevators, and in compliance with
Ohio R. C. 4105.1 to 4105.21 regulating the inspection of elevators by the
Division of Factory and Building Inspection.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.13 PERMITS.
   (a)   Except in cases where no permit is required by this chapter, no
electrical wiring, devices or equipment shall be installed within or on any
building, structure or premises, nor shall any alteration or addition be made
in any such existing wiring, devices or equipment without first securing a
permit.
   (b)   Failure to secure a permit prior to the commencement of electrical
work shall result in a double permit fee being charged based on the scope of
the work performed.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.14 TEN-DOLLARS LIMITATION; NO FEE REQUIRED.
   A permit shall be required, but no permit charge or inspection fee shall be
collected for installing, altering or repairing electrical wiring, devices or
equipment where the total cost of installing, altering or repairing the wiring,
devices or equipment does not exceed ten dollars ($10.00).
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.15 SIGNAL AND CONTROL WIRING; NO FEE REQUIRED.
   A permit shall be required, but no permit charge or inspection fee shall be
collected for the installation of wiring, devices or equipment for the
operation of signals, control circuits or the transmission of intelligence
where the wiring, devices or equipment operates at a voltage not exceeding
fifty volts between conductors.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.16 PERMIT APPLICATIONS; METER TRANSFERS.
   (a)   Applications for permits shall be made in writing to the Electrical
Inspector's office by the individual, partnership or corporation installing the
wiring, devices or equipment. The permits shall state and cover the wiring in
accordance with the schedule of inspection fees for electrical installations.
No meter shall be transferred from the inside to the outside of any residence
without the permission of the owner of the residence.
   (b)   Any person legally entitled to apply for and receive a permit shall
make the application on forms provided for that purpose. He shall give a
description of the character of the work proposed to be done, and the location,
ownership, occupancy and use of the premises in connection therewith. The
Electrical Inspector may require plans, specifications, drawings and other
information as he may deem necessary. If the Electrical Inspector determines
that the plans, specifications, drawings, description or information furnished
by the applicant are in compliance with this Electrical Code, he shall issue
the permit applied for upon payment of the required fee as hereinafter fixed.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.17 INSPECTION FEES.
   Inspection fees shall be charged according to the schedule of fees as
established by the Director of Engineering Services and approved by the City
Manager, which shall be published in the Office of the Department of
Engineering Services plus any additional fees assessed by the state regulatory
agency.
(Ord. 03-161. Passed 10-14-03.)
   1349.18 (RESERVED).
   1349.19 ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR QUALIFICATIONS AND APPOINTMENT.
   The person chosen to fill the office of Electrical Inspector shall be a
competent electrician of good moral character; shall be possessed of such
executive ability as is requisite for the efficient performance of his duties;
shall have a thorough knowledge of the standard materials and methods used in
the installation of electrical wiring, devices and equipment; shall be well
versed in approved methods of electrical construction for safety to life and
property, the statutes of the State relating to electrical work, the rules and
regulations issued under authority of the statutes and the National Electrical
Code, its supplements and revisions. The Electrical Inspector shall meet all
other requirements as provided by the statutes of the State.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.20  DUTIES OF THE ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR.
   (a)   The Electrical Inspector shall be appointed by the City Manager.
   (b)   The Electrical Inspector shall see that the provisions of this chapter
are enforced and he shall make inspections of all electrical installations as
provided in this chapter. he shall also serve as an ex-officio member of the
Examining Board of Electricians. He shall perform other duties as may hereafter
be assigned or prescribed by the City Manager.
   (c)   The Electrical Inspector shall require submission of, examine and
check plans and specifications, drawings, descriptions or diagrams necessary to
show clearly the character, kind and extent of electrical work covered by
applicants for a permit, and upon approval thereof, shall issue the permit
applied for.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.21 AUTHORITY OF ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR FOR REASONABLE ACCESS; RIGHT TO
DISCONNECT WIRES; NUISANCES DECLARED.
   (a)   The Electrical Inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours
to enter any building in the discharge of his official duties or for the
purpose of making inspection, reinspection or testing of the installation of
electrical wiring devices and equipment contained therein; and shall have the
authority to cut or disconnect any wire in cases of emergency where necessary
for safety to life or property, or where wires may interfere with the work or
progress of the Fire Department. The Electrical Inspector shall be empowered to
disconnect or order discontinuance of electrical service to any electrical
wiring, devices or equipment found to be dangerous to life or property because
they are defective or defectively installed, until the wiring, devices,
equipment and their installation have been made safe and have been approved by
the Electrical Inspector.
   (b)   Wherever the existing electrical service wiring, devices or equipment
are found by the Electrical Inspector to be detrimental to the health of the
occupants of the building or to the public, he shall declare the work to be a
nuisance and shall condemn it in accordance with the applicable provisions of
this Electrical Code, ordering that the installation be caused to meet the
minimum requirements of this Electrical Code or be removed.
(Ord.87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.22  ROUGH-IN INSPECTION; TICKET OF APPROVAL.
   When the Electrical Contractor has completed any portion of the wiring that
will be concealed within a building, he shall notify the Electrical Inspector,
who shall, within a reasonable time of notification, inspect the portion
completed. If the portion should pass inspection, the Electrical Inspector
shall leave his ticket of approval covering that part of the installations.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.23 FINAL INSPECTION.
   When the Electrical Contractor has completed the entire installation of
wiring, devices and equipment, with the exception of the fixtures, he shall
notify the Electrical Inspector, who shall, within a reasonable time of
notification, inspect the complete installation. If the installation should
pass inspection, the Electrical Inspector shall leave his ticket of approval
covering the completed installation. After the fixtures are installed and ready
for service, the Electrical Contractor shall notify the Electrical Inspector,
who shall, within a reasonable time, inspect the same. If the completed
installation should pass inspection, then the Electrical Inspector shall notify
the local electric utility of the completion of the job and authorize
connection to the installation. (Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.24 APPROVAL REQUIRED.
   No wiring shall be concealed from sight or shall be used or supplied with
electrical current, until approved by the Electrical Inspector. No wiring,
other than conduit, shall be installed in any building until all ventilating,
heating and plumbing mains and risers have been installed, except where plans
are submitted showing the exact locations of all wiring, ventilating, heating
and plumbing systems. (Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.25 NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE; COMPLIANCE; COMPLAINTS.
   All installations shall be in strict conformity with the provisions of this
chapter and the statutes of the State and shall be in conformity with approved
standards of construction for safety to life and property. Conformity with the
published regulations, as set forth in the National Electrical Code, being the
latest published edition thereof, as it now is or may hereafter be amended, its
supplements and revisions, shall be prima facie evidence of conformity with
approved standards. In case of complaint or controversy, the Examining Board
shall have the responsibility for making interpretations of the rules of the
National Electrical Code, for deciding upon the approval of devices, equipment
and materials, and for granting the special permission contemplated in a number
of the rules of the National Electrical Code. The decisions of the Examining
Board shall be made in writing. Where special conditions are mentioned in the
National Electrical Code, and where permission for the approval of devices,
equipment and materials is required thereunder, the Examining Board shall make
its ruling covering the conditions or permission in writing, after due
consideration of the facts.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.26 SERVICE ENTRANCE AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS.
   In addition to the requirements of Section
1349.25, the following additional requirements and standards are set for safety
to life and property.
(a)   Service entrance. Service equipment installed, irrespective to type,
shall be of such capacity as to permit the full utilization of the capacity of
the service entrance conductors installed at the time of the original
installation.
(b)   Distribution panels. Distribution panels for residential use shall be of
the following minimum capacities: one-family dwelling, 100-ampere; two-family
dwelling, each unit, 100-ampere; multiple-family units, each unit, sixty
ampere. All branch circuits shall be of the automatic circuit breaker type.
(c)   Grounding of Electrical Services. Where the water line is used as the
main grounding electrode, the grounding conductor shall be connected as near as
practical to the water line point of entry in the building and on the main
trunk line.
(d)   Metal siding. All dwellings and buildings with metal siding or covering
shall be grounded at the corners.
(e)   The raceways used to install service entrance conductors from the meter
base to the main disconnecting means shall be of a metallic wiring system,
acceptable with the present edition of the National Electrical Code.
      (Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.27 BUILDING CLASSIFICATION; REQUIREMENTS; DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   All wiring systems acceptable to the National Electrical Code shall be
acceptable for use in the City as stated in this subsection and subsections (b)
to (e) hereof. These systems shall be installed using the strict requirements
and conditions of the latest edition of the National Electrical Code. All
wiring systems shall be installed using proper fittings, connectors, couplings,
insulators, etc., which are listed and labeled for the specified purpose by an
appropriate testing laboratory. Proper cutting tools, crimping tools, bending
tools, etc. specified by the manufacturer of the wiring method, shall be used
when installing each system. Manufacturers' specifications shall be followed
when installing all wiring systems and equipment.
   (b)   Types AC and MC cables, with an internal bonding strip and all
nonmetallic wiring methods shall only be acceptable when an insulated equipment
grounding conductor, sized in accordance to Table 250-95 of the National
Electrical Code is contained in the cable assembly or conduit with the circuit
conductors.
   (c)   (1)   Rigid nonmetallic conduit containing service entrance conductors
and emerging from the ground or floor shall be installed in schedule 80 or
rigid metal conduit, for example, service entrance laterals (underground)
between the transformer and meter base or main disconnect.
(2)   Where other wiring is judged by the Electrical Inspector to be subject to
physical damage, schedule 80 PVC or rigid metal conduit shall be used.
   (d)   Aluminum wire shall only be acceptable for service entrance purposes
up to the main disconnecting means. The internal wiring of a building, after
the main service disconnect, shall be installed using only copper conductors.
   (e)   (1)   In mercantile/commercial and industrial/plant installations,
only metallic wiring methods, rigid nonmetallic conduit, electrical nonmetallic
tubing and nonmetallic liquidtite shall be acceptable within or upon these
buildings.
(2)   In residential multiple family installations (three or more dwelling
units), nonmetallic wiring methods (NM, UF, SE, SNM) cables shall be acceptable
within or upon these buildings only where these methods are concealed, with
approved fire separation between each individual dwelling unit and also between
each individual dwelling unit and the buildings common areas (hallways,
entrances, etc.). All installations, one and two-family residential, multiple
family, residential, mercantile/commercial and industrial/plant, shall comply
with the NEC as stated in subsection (a) hereof and Section
1349.25.
   (f)   "Mercantile/commercial building", for the purpose of this chapter,
means any building which, in whole or in part, is used for any purpose
whatsoever other than plants (see Section
1349.09) or private dwellings designed to house not more than two families.
(Ord. 05-119. Passed 7-25-05.)
   1349.28  SIGNAL WIRES, REMOVAL AND REPLACEMENT.
   All City signal or light wires removed for any cause shall be replaced to
the satisfaction of the Electrical Inspector by the parties removing the same.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.29 FIRES, EMERGENCY ACTION; REPAIR OR RENEWAL.
   (a)   The Chief of the City Fire Department, the Electrical Inspector or
some other competent person delegated by them, or either of them, shall have
the authority to cause the turning off of all electrical currents and to cut or
disconnect, in cases of emergency, any wires where electrical currents are
dangerous to life or property, or where the wires may interfere with the work
or progress of the Fire Department.
   (b)   Any building or structure, in which the electrical wiring has been
damaged or rendered defective by fire, shall have a free fire demand
certificate posted in it by the Electrical Inspector specifying what portion or
portions of the electrical wiring shall be repaired or renewed.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.30 LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES.
   This chapter shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the
responsibility or liability of any person owning, operating, controlling or
installing any electrical wiring, devices or equipment for damage to person or
property caused by any defect therein; nor shall the City be held as assuming
any liability by reason of the inspection authorized herein or certificate of
approval issued as herein provided.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.31 NO ELECTRIC PERMIT REQUIRED FOR REPLACEMENT OF HEATING/AIR
CONDITIONING EQUIPMENT.
   (a)   Mechanical contractors shall not be required to obtain electrical
permits or licenses when installing their add-on or replacement equipment
(furnaces , air conditioners, heat pump, circulating pumps, etc.), in existing
one or two-family residential dwellings only. The electrical work may consist
of installing a properly sized, single phase 120V-240V single circuit directly
to the panel. This shall be a dedicated circuit for the specific equipment
only. The circuit shall be properly identified at the service panel. The
electrical panel shall have the capacity to accept the circuit(s) both
electrically and physically. If the panel does not have the capacity to
facilitate the new circuit(s) for the equipment, a licensed electrical
contractor shall be required to make the necessary changes to the panel and/or
service and install all related wiring to the equipment with proper permits.
   (b)   This special permission granted to the mechanical contractors shall
not pertain to any new work or construction and not to commercial, mercantile
or industrial installations. Mechanical contractors shall not be permitted to
install or alter any wiring using a homeowner's permit issued to the owner of
the dwelling. All electrical work performed shall be subject to inspection and
approval by the City. The installations shall meet all existing National
Electrical Code requirements and amendments hereafter.
(Ord. 87-077. Passed 7-20-87.)
   1349.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Any person, firm, partnership or corporation which fails to comply
with any of the provisions of this chapter, or with any of the requirements
thereof or any regulations hereunder, or with a valid order of the Electrical
Inspector pursuant to Sections
1349.20 and
1349.21 shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense. Each and every day that the violation continues shall constitute a
separate offense.
   (b)   An imposition of the penalties prescribed herein shall not preclude
the City Director of Law from instituting an appropriate action or proceeding
at law or in equity to restrain, correct or abate the violation of the order of
the Building Official under the provisions of this chapter, or to prevent the
occupancy of a building, structure or premises contrary to the provisions of
this chapter.
(Ord. 90-117. Passed 11-26-90.)
